But when my family moved them near us, I began visiting every weekend. Despite our silence, I felt grandma's warmth as she smiled at me. When I moved to Canada, I called home often and was urged to speak with grandma, who surprised me by crying. This emotional moment made me realize her adoration for me. When I returned to South Korea, I visited her more regularly, growing closer during my high school years. College separated us, but visits during breaks became treasured moments. When she fell ill with cancer, my fear of death kept me from visiting her in the hospice until I finally sat by her side. She passed away the next day, and I regretted not visiting more. Her love for me became clear, and her absence weighed heavily on me. Reflecting on her life, I realized how lonely it must have been for her, caring for my grandfather. In a dream, she appeared vibrant and happy, bringing me comfort and relieving my guilt. Seeing her well and happy in my dream helped me find solace and wish her peace and happiness.

This event is, quite simply, just a conversation I had with my wife about our future. It was a happy conversation that just happened randomly, about a month ago. We were plopped on our couch and just resting when my wife started a conversation about our future, about having our first baby. I was engaged. 

We started discussing how he or she would look like, who we want it to look like, how we will raise our child, and how fun (and simultaneously stressful) it would be to be a parent. It was a very meaningful and satisfying conversation. 

We normally don't have time available to just sit and talk like that. We live pretty busy lives. But that moment was really significant, because it meant something to us and what our future will be as husband and wife. 

We talked about how we have been married for over three years already, and we already enjoyed most of our time with just the two of us. It may be time for a new member to join in. We feel quite ready. 

I told her however if we can wait just a few more months before trying. I just want to have one more special anniversary to spend with her, then we can finally go for it. She agreed. 

It was a special time we shared having that conversation. It means a lot to us to share what we think openly, and be very loving and understanding of our thoughts and feelings. 

This event is something we would definitely look back at once we have our first kid.

So, since we are talking about moving to a new place, I wanted to share my story about my history of my relocation and how my perspective in life has changed since then. I've been living in different countries since I was young, in Canada, India, and now in the US, originally born and raised in South Korea, so I've lived in four different countries. I also traveled to many different countries like Japan, Europe, and Southeast Asia. I guess I enjoyed a nomadic lifestyle because I am a person with a lot of curiosity and like exploring something new. The excitement of exploring new places outweighs the desire to settle down and feel stable. Part of my changed perspective is because I've moved three times this year already and I'm tired of packing and unpacking. I'm more focused on my career development and expertise now, and feel like I've found a career and a job I can dedicate my life to. I want my environment to be more stable in order to do a better job at what I'm doing. My taste has been developing, I have lots of books, magazines, photography equipment, drawing tablets, and computer for video editing. It's annoying to bring all these things around, so I want to settle down. I really want to buy land and build my own house to reflect my personality and interests in the next couple of years. I still need to figure out where I want to settle down, number one homework before purchasing a house. My perspective and lifestyle have evolved from a nomadic one to someone seeking more stability in settlement.

Today, I'd like to share how my perspective on happiness changed throughout my life. Since I was really young, I kinda knew how difficult life would be, with a lot of responsibilities and pain involved. As I grew up, I wanted to avoid pain and pursue only happiness. For me, happiness meant status without pain, with only joy and pleasure. So as a teenager and college student, I hated doing things I didn't want to do, like studying subjects I wasn't interested in. I only wanted to study things I enjoyed. This mindset hindered my growth because I always avoided painful situations. Looking back, I understand that now. Since I was young, I was interested in Buddhism, which talked about breaking out of painful life and reaching endless peace. In my early 20s, I practiced Buddhism, including meditation. My perspective on happiness slowly changed as I was exposed to military content. The popularity of ex-Navy SEALs and army officers inspired me to embrace pain and go through difficult situations willingly. My interest shifted to MMA fighters and UFC, who go through tough training. I realized my level of happiness never changes. Achieving goals only brings temporary joy. When my environment changed, I thought I would be miserable forever, but I got used to it after a few days. I realized happiness is always with me, regardless of life's ups and downs. Painful experiences help me realize that I'll always be okay. I don't need to avoid pain or pursue happiness. That's how my perspective on happiness evolved over the years.

I have a friend who recently lost his father due to a tragic car accident. I heard this news on a day of going for dinner. I felt really bad for my friend because I know how kind and sweet of a person he is. Although I haven't seen his father, I could see that he must have grown in a very happy family. He talked about his father a couple of times, so I know that he loves his family and his father. I know how difficult it would be for him. It was very difficult for me as well, thinking about it. I feel like nothing could comfort him in this situation. I felt really bad that I could not do much for him. It got me to think about my own family. How would I feel if my dad suddenly passed away? I couldn't even imagine that. I have a really good relationship with my dad, and I talk with him about everything. Losing someone that important, that close, who supports you and made you actually would be unimaginable. I've experienced that with my grandparents, but I think it's very different from losing your parents. It got me thinking about relationships and death in life. I think it's inevitable. I will die someday and see my parents die someday. So, I should always take the moments in time preciously because it's not going to last forever. This tragic event with my friend got me thinking a lot about those kinds of philosophical questions. Sometimes, just thinking about that makes me feel so humble and makes me feel like everything is less important than I am actually thinking it is. But yeah, I don't know how to... I guess I'm trying to think on a brighter side. It can also broaden my perspective somehow and embrace the difficult moments in life as more grateful. I was very heartbroken to hear my friend's youth. Yeah, I just thought I wanted to share this story to hear what you think about.

Okay, so this isn't really anything exciting, it's not an exciting story, but it's something that I learned recently about myself, so I thought it'd be interesting to share. Wait, let me take a look at my note. When I was younger, I really wanted to achieve something in life really fast and be recognized as a successful person, so I had this very big desire. Naturally, I searched for a field or area where I thought I had a competitive advantage, and one of the fields or professions that I found I could do better than other people was in the creative writing field. I got a lot of compliments from teachers and family and friends about my writing skills or my imagination. In my early twenties, I wanted to become a famous novelist, a successful TV scriptwriter, or a filmmaker, so I did internships and worked as a writer at a radio station, a production company, and a youth agency. But I didn't last long in those fields because I was so impatient and wanted to be this famous writer, but I was just a low-paying freelance writer and couldn't bear the difficulties. I called it quits and jumped to another industry. Looking back, I realize I was immature and impatient at the time. If I was a little bit wiser, I would have seen those struggles and difficulties as learning opportunities to grow. Now I'm in a completely different field not related to writing, although writing is essential in all kinds of work and industry. I've learned my lesson from past experiences, and although today I felt like my younger self was feeling agitated about who I am right now and was comparing myself to who I want to be in the future, I try to remind myself of the outcome that I had with that kind of mentality. I'm trying to reinforce myself in a more positive way and enjoy the moment rather than jump to the end result. I'm trying to be grateful about my surroundings and who I am right now. It's good for my mind and gives me motivation and energy to continue to work on my future goals.

Cool. So today, I was looking at photos of some friends, it was a friend's birthday today. I was looking at photos from maybe ten years, from 2006 to probably 2014. I guess maybe somewhere around there. Anyways, I was just thinking about how my friends and I used to go hike in college, have fun, and build forts. We were already old, but it was still fun to do that. I was sending some photos to some other friends, and I was just thinking about a vacation that we went on in high school, that was wild and fun. It was just interesting to see photos of us from when we were younger. It made me think of how young we were, how young I was, and how much we've all grown. We look different, we were different. We were closer friends then, and now we're all grown up. Some of my friends are lawyers, and I work in artificial intelligence. It was just interesting to look back on those photos today and back on photos throughout my life. But particularly on the photos of my friends. It's nice, I guess, to remember being so close to those people, even though we were all young and it was messy. We weren't responsible adults, emotionally or in any other way. But it was nice to be so close with my friends during those years past.

Yeah, so I was talking with my father last night, and he was repeating himself a lot. He mentioned that his wife is concerned about his cognitive decline in terms of dementia. Some of my earlier memories were with my grandfather, his father, who had Alzheimer's, and he lived in our house. It was pretty brutal to see him losing his mind. But I told my father that I don't think it's related to Alzheimer's or Dementia. I think he just lacks intellectual or emotional stimulation. He doesn't engage in conversations, participate in social events, or ask questions to learn about people. He has no interest in using a computer, buying a plane ticket, traveling alone, or managing his finances. He essentially does nothing. In my opinion, his lack of participation and cognitive processes are a self-fulfilling process of his decline. There are older people I know who love learning, cooking, reading, hiking, and exploring ways to stay active and healthy. My father prefers sitting on the couch, jogging, and drinking beer. It's been that way his whole life. It's annoying to hear him say, "Oh, Jamie's worried about me," when it's really due to his own preferences and behaviors.

Are you listening? Right now, I guess I'll start, I'm not sure if you're listening, I guess. The two most meaningful stories we can start out with are from the beginning. I can tell you the story of my adoption: I was born in Seoul, South Korea, and at about the age somewhere between eight to 15 months, I was abandoned on post office steps and then taken to an orphanage, where my adoption was arranged for my family at about 21 months. From what I know, I was abandoned on post office steps and then taken to an orphanage, and then my family was tracked down. I was told that my birth father was deceased and my birth mother couldn't take care of me. After they had contacted my family, my birth uncle tried to take care of me, but he just couldn't handle it, so then I was released for the adoption process. So, at about 21 months, I came over to the United States to my current loving, loving family. I feel very fortunate and I never kind of felt empty inside about the whole adoption. I get a little emotional just talking about it because honestly, it feels very surreal. I've always had a very loving family and so there's nothing that I should be feeling bad about. I was lucky to have my parents have two biological children, John and Betsy, who are about eight and nine years older than me, so I was definitely the baby of the family, but I never grew up feeling different. In fact, sometimes I joke that I'm just a white girl, which might seem a little derogatory, but I have never felt different or undervalued in my life. Well, from this, if anything, I feel very blessed and fortunate to have landed where I did and all the immense opportunities that have been before me. I really, honestly couldn't feel luckier about the family that I had.

I'll do a part two to my adoption story, something that surfaced when I was about 25 years old, quite a while after my adoption. I took a graduate study and we traveled to Korea, my first time back to Seoul, South Korea, since my adoption. I don't know if I've had that many emotions running through me at any other point in my life. It was just such a blend of elevated highs of feeling connected and moments of pure peace to extreme disruption with who I identified with up until that point. I even took a little medallion that was from when I came over, with the name of my orphanage, and had a cab driver take me there. I saw all the kids there and they showed me a picture of myself that I had never seen before. It completely threw me into a complete unraveling, having panic attacks for a good two weeks plus after that, where I couldn't breathe, and didn't know who I was or where I was supposed to be going. It took a long time for me to kind of situate myself back to "I am a blend of everything. I'm not just one or the other." I don't have to feel guilty or wonder about my birth family and where they are, but it really did take a long time for me to calm down my emotions so I wasn't having panic attacks anymore. I still feel like it has a bit of a ripple effect.

I don't know if it's interesting. I'm kind of gearing more towards emotional triggers in my storytelling about having to work with a really aggressive coworker. So I have a product manager who is, I can flat out say, the most aggressive teammate I've ever had to deal with. The way that I started to handle it was first to be overly appeasing and make sure that she felt included. It just continued, this perpetual sort of resentment towards me. I'm not really sure where that's founded in. she just had something she didn't like about me and brought it to a personal level rather than keeping it professional. I tried to have heart-to-hearts with her and it seemed on the surface that everything was fine. But it's really just constant and perpetual condescending tones, outright aggression, and honestly, very childish behavior. The outcome is just that thankfully the teams have shuffled and I shouldn't have to have any overlap with her. I've brought it up to my boss, my manager, and he's fully aware of it. We have such a limited fund and appetite for hiring new people. The only resolution is to basically not have to overlap with her in work.

I have been in this ATM business racket for many many years. I got my start in a great company but like many others say appreciate what you have now because one day it can be gone. In this case though I have to say don't always look back at memories and be prepared for what's to come. The company that I loved to work for got bought out by a major conglomerate in the business. We all were worried about losing our jobs which they assured was not the case. 

Sometimes some things are better left unsaid. My entire department was let go in one swoop but were picked up by another service company in the same industry. We all knew we were just buying time at that point and i noticed one by one several of my coworkers were going their own way. 

Luckily for me i was headhunted by my former manager to another job which i didn't think was a great opportunity at the time. In the mean time of all this moving I was keen on becoming part of this company I've always been fond of, some of my coworkers even started working there. 

For 2 years i applied and most of the time did not receive a response. Then one day the call came, I was so excited i ran around my block with joy. The salary they promised was so outstanding and just the fact i would work with familiar faces made me so excited. 

To this day i love where i work, and I even intend on going to college to further pursue my career within the company. How my life changed since that day is something i will never forget. I will always never forget the path it took to get here and most importantly how God was able to guide me.

I guess recently, I don't know if I've been talking about the lack of security at my job because we're a venture-backed kind of product company. We really rely on outside financing to help support our growth and development. There's been a lot of uncertainty now with this last venture capitalist backing, investment opportunity, whether or not our company is going to survive. I've been dealing a lot with the nervousness about job security. I reached out to my friend who works at another product design company. There's a really great potential opportunity over there. I feel like I'm my own worst enemy. I weigh the balances, which I guess is normal, but at the same time sometimes I already talk myself out of opportunities before I even jump into them because I'm weighing all the outcomes and seeing outcomes that probably don't even exist. Maybe just looking for reasons not to lean into something. I struggle with this. It sounds perfect and great, but it's kind of a whole 100% remote, and so, I just already have predetermined in my mind that for the rest of my life, I'm going to be working at home in my office by myself. I shouldn't just talk myself out of good opportunities.

I have a job interview coming up, and I had maybe 15 different recruiters reach out to me about it, with a bunch giving the same cap for what the company would pay. There's a contract rule, but it's Google and they can pay so much more since I live in the heart of Boston. It's not just a typical research role, it's a team lead role. Dealing with the recruiters is its own beast, but they're there to hopefully gain success through my success, so that's good. Sometimes you have to wonder how transparent they're being about budget, but it's a cool opportunity with a lot of competition and it's contract. I have mixed feelings about that, but since I'm still not really sure of my next direction, I should see where things take me. I have to be discerning, otherwise I just pick up an available job, which is not what I want. I like to pride myself on the opportunities I select, and hopefully, girlfriend... I'm needing to refresh myself in some of my old work because I have had so many different jobs and projects that really vary but are still within UX, user research, Psychology, perception, and design research. There are so many different directions I can take myself in the field still, which is exciting.

My family and I just came back from a camping trip yesterday. I wanted to do one last mini vacation before my child started school today. It was a great 3 day weekend. On Friday my family and I left for our camping trip to Perris Lake in Perris, California. Perris is 2 hours away from us so we actually went and stayed with a friend on Friday that lived one hour away from the lake. 

On Saturday was the start of our camping trip. It was hot, 105 plus degree temperatures everyday, trust me I will never forget that. Good thing the lake was not too far from the campsite. We went with 5 of our friends. The best thing was my child got to to see one of her friends that she had not seen over a year because they moved four hours away. I had a great time. The lake was nice and refreshing. We had a couple of canoes with us so we went out exploring the lake. We had great food from the grill and fresh fruits to keep us fresh because of the heat. 

The last night, on Sunday there was a storm off in the distance. We had a great lighting storm and a little wind. Luckily, it did not rain. I know now not to go camping here in the late summer because the heat was too much for me, I had mixed feeling from this camping trip because I was happy to be around some great friends I had not seen in while but the heat was awful.

All right? So, my story is that I got to catch up with my friend today. It was really nice talking about different trips we've taken in the past. Other trips we might want to take in the future. And also just finding out the best way to plan for taking a trip with her because she has a baby. I'm friends with her husband, but it's different when you're single and you're figuring out how to hang out with your friends. Go on trips with them when they aren't single. And it makes sense this time of my life. I mean, I've got friends that have kids going to college. I've got friends that have kids they just had. And of course, people like myself, like I was just mentioning. But it was really good. So, the story is that I met up with her for lunch. And she was telling me also about how she's going through IVF right now to get pregnant again. And so, that was also really interesting because I've gone through my own process of trying to cryogenically freeze my own eggs. Which I've done in the past after my husband passed away. So, I have some experience in that, not in the implanting stage. The fertilization stage. But she's having to inject all these hormones into her right now. And I've gone through that and can commiserate. It can change you not just physically. But mentally too. So, it's good we can share different past experiences. Whether it's her experience going to Sedona. Or my experience with IVF. Just a lot to talk about. A lot of different kinds of topics. And she's a fun friend to discuss a lot of different topics with.

So this is a story of how my mom and dad got married, they have a super cute love story that I wish I will have. They grew up on the same little street in a tiny farming fishing village in China, just a few houses apart. My mom is two years older than my dad, but he fell in love with her from birth. She was the class star, President, role model, most beautiful girl ever. He followed her around, made dumb jokes, but she kind of liked them a little bit. When he left for the US at twelve, they didn't see each other for six years. He wrote letters and kept loving her. He deferred a semester to go back to China for College, and saw my mom first thing. He just knew. He asked her to come to America and eventually marry him. She agreed, never dating anyone before. My maternal grandma was strict about boys. They were each other's first kiss, everything. Very bold and brave of my mom to move to America with my dad. They got married at 20 and 22, married for over 30 years now. I admire that. I hope to find someone soon. That is the story of how my mom fell in love, got married, and had six years of marriage before having me. A little marriage time before kids is nice. Thank you, Jibo.

So this past weekend, I went to my first wedding ever. The groom was my peer mentor, the one that introduced me to MIT and the dorm we lived in. He took care of me and my friends. The bride was in my year but one year younger. They met through shared interests. The ceremony was outside, with cute vows that almost made me cry a lot. The reception got to me. Both dads gave beautiful speeches and their first dance was touching. The friend group, except for the guys, were crying. It made me think about my future wedding, partner, and marriage. The couple isn't on their honeymoon yet, as she has a conference first. It's crazy how life can change fast. I flew in Saturday morning and commuted an hour and a half to a nice udon place. I'm not famous, but kind of. I spent 2 hours getting ready. Dressing up was fun, catching up, spilling some tea. We made our way to the hotel for the wedding. A lot of us didn't know what to do and arrived too early. It was still fun. I ran into random people I knew and extended my trip because I loved it. That was the story of the first wedding I've ever been to.

Yeah, so the story I'm going to share today is about my family's move from Hino, Texas. My favorite part about that house, besides family, was that on the front lawn, the sidewalk, there my sister and I have our handprints in the cement. So they redid our sidewalk at some point. But as kids, we were like, "Ha, ha. Wouldn't it be so funny if we left our mark in the cement on the sidewalk here, just to mark our place, that we were here?" So each of us put our right hand down into the cement when it was so, not wet, but not dry either, and left little handprints there. It's been like ten years now, and I still think about our handprints there, but eventually my family did move. I was very sad at first because we were taking out all the furniture, repainting the walls. When we left, the house just felt so empty, like foreign, like a shell of itself. I didn't recognize it after we painted the walls white. Everything was echoing, and I was like, "Wow, I grew up here. This is no longer home." Part of me thought we would always have this home for the rest of my life to come back to. But then we moved to our new house in Allen, Texas. I really quickly adjusted to it because the furniture was the same. Obviously, home is where my parents are. So if they move again, that will be my new home. But now I love our new home a lot; it's much bigger, much more comfortable. Interestingly, I still dream sometimes about my old home, dreams where I mix my old home and my new home's architectural layout. It's confusing, but the move was fun. We started in COVID summer, so I was home. Luckily, we're just moving things back and forth with our cars. The move itself was not too bad; it was definitely a bonding moment within our family to move our stuff ourselves. What do you think? So, yeah. We moved. Now that's my new home. I know that my parents will eventually move at least one more time. They will probably downsize their home once the grandkids are older enough that they don't need to visit and have their own guest rooms. So, I'm excited for that. Oh, no. Another home missing. But yes, the story. That was the story of my family moving from one house to another house.

So today, my story is about the movie I watched yesterday, named Joyride. I think it was really interesting because when they first introduced the characters, I was actually a little bit upset. I was like, "Why are they getting a Korean girl to play a Chinese girl?" Right? I understand Asian American representation is really important, especially in media nowadays. But later, spoiler alert, there's a twist. It turns out she was supposed to be Korean. So I was like, "Whoa, it's so nice that they actually got ethnicities correct." So I changed my mind about casting. Overall, I really enjoyed the movie. It was about finding out who you are. The storyline goes that there's this fancy lawyer who was adopted from China, trying to find her birth mother. They go through a crazy adventure and eventually end up in Korea. She finds out that her birth mother was Korean and had passed away. It tested their friendship. They did a lot of really crazy things while in East Asia. But overall, I think it was a pretty beautiful message of friendship and how family and your identities are what you make of it, and at the end of the day, just love your people who love you. So I really enjoyed the movie. It's really, really funny at times. Really emotional sometimes, I definitely cried a little bit at one point when the deceased mother was wishing her daughter well. And it kind of inspired me, too. I think I also want to go on like a soul-searching journey. Yes, that is my story.

So, I'm actually going to be flying home in 3 hours, or leaving for the airport in 3 hours to fly home, and something I've been super excited for—cannot wait. Definitely miss my parents a lot. My younger sister is in New York, so she won't be home, but going home will be good for me because I really need the rest. I think something that's really hard to do as an adult is to pace yourself, because when you're in school, you have semesters, you have projects that you know when they'll end, so you have better timelines to fulfill. Like, "Oh, you know, in two weeks, then you have an exam and then you have a period of free time," but until then, you're working hard. But in grad school, I feel like there's just no end, so if you need a break, you have to really go take that break for yourself. For us, you just won't have that break. So the last time I was home was probably early June for two days, home trips are very short. Now I miss having a full week at home, a whole actual vacation. So being able to go home for just like three days this weekend will be very helpful, healing, good for my soul. Yeah, I am most excited to eat my mom's food, to go shopping, to feel like a kid again. I feel like life is very tiring and pressurising, to be able to let loose and let someone take care of me for a little bit will be nice. I did try to take care of my parents as well, I bring them gifts, I listen to them when they're lonely, and I hope that their parents can take good care of them when my grandparents are in China, so they're not really close by. It's a very different relationship between my mom and her mom, which is my mom and me, but I'm so grateful for my family, everything about it. So yeah, I left lab a little early today to catch my flight, talking to you now before Doica's over or the week begins, and yeah, I'll be sad when I come back, but I'm mostly looking forward to going home first. Yeah.

Tuesday, yeah. So this Tuesday, I played squash for the very first time, and today's Friday, so it's been three days and I'm still very sore from it. But it was my first time really trying something new in a while. I played with a couple of upperclassmen, and as a perfectionist, it's really hard for me to show my failure weakness. But what was really nice about the whole situation was that everyone was super friendly, even though I kept missing the ball, and it really made me feel a lot better about myself. I can't explain how silly it sounds, but for my upperclassmen friends to be so supportive of me, messing up, failing, and being nice playing the ball was really nice. When the guys played against each other, they were like, "swing real hard, the ball is going so fast, so hard." But when they played against me and another girl, they were a lot easier on us, which is kind of gentlemanly of them, I think. Yeah. The point was that I was able to fail a lot and be really bad at a sport and not feel really ashamed of it, so it was a really good first experience, and I definitely will play again sometime (unsure when) because I'm still so sore, and it did take a very long time to get there. But overall, I really enjoyed the experience. So that was the story of me playing squash for the first time and not being afraid of not being perfect.

I saw a movie that I enjoyed so much I saw it three times in the last week. I first went to it alone. Then I went to it with my husband. Then I took my girlfriend to see it last night. The movie was about an event that was a fantasy and yet totally believable. The characters were sweet and lovely and they made you want to know what happened to them and you really cared about what happened. The music in the movie was so phenomenal and kept you on the edge of your seat. I also had acquired the tickets for a really good price. That made it more justifiable to see it so many times. 

I intend to buy the movie when it becomes available. I may see it again soon with my son who wants to see it too and has not done so yet. The movie just makes me happy when I see it because of the joyfulness. The way they overcome their challenges with love and understanding is so lovely. It makes you want to persevere in the things you love as well. 

The actors that portrayed the characters in the movie were remarkable. They were so realistic that you totally believed what was happening to them. They also were humorous and had many friends. Movies that include friendship and love are so rare nowadays and that was refreshing. The fact that they were not white Americans was surprising but surprisingly a very good choice. It was sweet but not syrupy sweet. 

It was a fantasy and yet a believable story. The story was just a remarkable way of showing perseverance and love with ordinary people. I hope that the movie academy of arts and sciences will consider it for some award. It was a brilliant concept and a wonderful story to impart to all ages. I've been telling everyone I know about the movie now.

One of the prompts was to talk about a movie that meant something to you. When I was in high school, in the late 60s, this is when all the counterculture types were really into Tolkien and that was the first time that he became a phenomenon in this country. I was into it and just devoured the book, which made a big impression on me. I never dreamed that it would be possible to translate these books into film, but when the Peter Jackson movies came out, the special effects were more advanced and I think that Peter Jackson did a magnificent job with a story just true to Tolkien's vision. The actors were all just top notch. However, the single most memorable scene for me wasn't necessarily one of the big battle set pieces, but it was right at the beginning of the first movie when Gandalf weiss's cart into town and sees Frodo waiting alongside the road. Gandalf asks Frodo, "Get in the cart. We'll go into town together." And he does. Ian McKellen as Gandalf looks at Frodo and smiles at him with such unbelievable love, which just blows off the screen. You could see that Tolkien would have adored this portrayal of Gandalf. It's interesting that Ian McKellen just doesn't take acting all that seriously and has been on variety shows where he says, "Well, somebody else writes the lines. I just stand where I'm supposed to stand and read." But he is a summit actor and what he did with no words at all, just facial expressions, brought a whole Lord of the Rings feel of it in such an immediate way. I never forgot that.

Two years ago my mom passed away. It was the worst day of my life, and a day I will never forget. It was very unexpected and traumatic. It was a Sunday morning, and I got the call from my dad who told me she had passed. I just remember screaming, and not really being able to do much else. I told my husband and we both just cried and cried. 

I couldn't believe what was happening and was too young to lose my mom. I remember collapsing while trying to pack to fly to where she and my dad lived. I had a young daughter at the time and my heart was breaking for her that she would never get to know my mom. And that my mom wouldn't be able to get to know her. 

I mourned at the lost time and the major events my mom would not be a part of. It was heartbreaking. The rest of the day was a big blur, as I just went through the motions and didn't even really remember much. When we got to my parents house, we were surrounded by family and friends, but I felt so lonely. 

I remember just going into her room, and crying thinking how could this be happening. It was the worst day, and even 2 years later, it still is hard to breathe when I think about it. She died from pneumonia. Something that happens all the time to people, but it took my mom. Emotionally it has been so daunting. Losing someone you love that much is so hard, and is not something you ever get over. 

The days get easier to get through, but that moment is always in the back of your mind, and the person lost is always thought of.

I think I've mentioned that I have a cat named Zoro, right? His name is Zoro. I adopted him when my other cat was about ten years old. Sadly, my other cat passed away a couple of years ago, and he was just super, like the best cat ever. When I got Zoro, he was only five months old. And then, my ex-husband, he got home before me from grad school. His brother had come over and he wasn't paying attention, and Zoro slipped out of the front door. It was terrifying. The doorway is very narrow, so you really have to not be paying attention to have Zoro slip by. I was scared because I was living in Florida, and my apartment was near a nature conservation area. There are dangerous animals like gators, alligators, venomous snakes, and even hawks that could be predators to Zoro. He was small enough to be prey for a hawk, and that was really close to my door. I looked everywhere for him. He didn't come back. So, the next day, I put on rain boots, tucked in my pants, put on a sweatshirt, and a bandana over my face. I went into the nature conservation area to find Zoro. It had been 18 hours since he disappeared, but I finally got close enough to the bush he was hiding under and he meowed. It was terrifying. I did run into a gator at one point, but I backed away slowly and thankfully, it didn't act aggressive. I was really worried. But I found him, and Zoro is with me today. I'm very glad it worked out.

Yeah, so this is the beginning of the school year, and I've seen a lot of people moving into their dorms and apartments, and it really got me thinking about when I first went to College, when I was moving into the dorm. How excited my parents were for me and scared. And I was both excited and scared, moving away from home and my parents, and knowing that I'd probably get really homesick. Watching all those kids moving in really made me think about how that felt for me. It was really important for me, there was a lot of pressure for me to do well in College because my dad came here from a developing country and wasn't able to get an education past second grade. I was the first person in my family to go to College, and to make it that far. So I had a lot of emotions, definitely some anxiety, some stress about the pressure of performing and doing well. But also the excitement, and kind of the normal fear that you get doing something you've never done before and not having parents who had never experienced College like that before. I didn't really have anyone to go to, to understand what that meant, like what to expect. So watching those kids just brought me back to that moment.

Here's my story today, maybe it's more a reflection than a story, but I just wanted to talk to you about my son's 40th birthday. It crept up on me, and that was interesting. He lives in another state, and now he's married with a child. We don't have a day-to-day communication relationship, so we catch each other when we can. Birthdays always make me reminisce about them growing up, both my sons. This one was my younger son. So different. You think about a day that we were born, when you drop them off at kindergarten, their first day, first grade, and on to dropping them off at college and all that, and then their wedding. It's a lot of emotions during the day when they have their birthday, it always seems to happen to me. Now he's 40, and he has his own life, his own family. Our conversations are so different now. It's no longer the parent-child conversation, it's two adults talking. He told me all about how his house is coming along, doing a lot of renovations, has a new job, and wanted to talk about his daughter starting second grade next week. It was all very pleasant. But it's so different. It's just how life evolves over the years, from parent child to a different kind of relationship. It is a little bit like the tables are turning. So a lot of memories in this city, a lot of memories. But that was today. It always happens during their birthdays. So that's my story today.

I almost killed someone last month. I was on the phone, helping a patient, and also filling prescriptions as fast as I could. The pharmacist in charge (PIC) was picking her nose while telling me to go faster, faster, faster. I felt so angry that she wouldn't even pick up the phone and put someone on hold while us techs were working at such dangerous paces.

And then it happened. A customer asked me to count their pills again so they knew they were receiving the right amount. I understood why, we were visibly overworked and understaffed, but was also very irritated at having yet another task added to my plate. I grabbed the vial, dumped it out, and then my blood ran cold. The PIC stopped digging in her nose and looked down at the same time I did--she lead by micromanaging us right down to how many times a day we urinated, and she started whisper yelling at me.

There was a very dangerous drug mixed in with the blood pressure pills. How it happened, who initially put the wrong drug in the wrong bottle, who verified it at the final check, it didn't matter. This was not a failure of the multi-step process or the team in her eyes. No, the fault was mine and mine alone.

My bladder was strained, my feet hurt, and I could not safely multitask another day. I went home and thought about it, obsessed over it, dreamed about it. I showed up for work the next day and worried over every patient. I worried that the other techs were not able to work safely either, that the other pharmacists were so worried about whether patients were coming in for vaccinations to meet a goal that I was actually going to kill someone next time. I worried that someone was sitting down to take the wrong medicine right that moment and there was nothing I could do.

The next day was my day off and I felt dread, crippling dread. And then I woke up at 3 in the morning and realized I didn't have to go in the next day. I didn't have to go back ever again. So without warning, without thought I quit. Just like that. My family is broke but I didn't kill someone that day.

One of my hobbies is origami, and I'm going to tell you about how I started getting into it when I was around 14 or 13. One day, the idea of making a paper dragon popped into my head, so I scoured the internet on YouTube for origami dragon instructions or a tutorial to find a model that looked cool. I settled on some pretty complex models, not really thinking about how difficult it would be to make. Since I had never really done origami before, except for simple paper planes and unpapercrafts, it was very difficult with hundreds of folds made with great precision. I tried over and over for a day, then another, and then a week, maybe 20 or 30 times, each taking hours, and couldn't seem to finish. Even during a journey, I was folding and folding, committing most of the folds to memory.

After about a month of trying, I finally finished making the model, sparking my love for origami and leading me to make many more models. I still enjoy doing origami, wanting to learn to design my own models and study the interesting math behind origami and research in the field. But most of all, I just enjoy the process of folding and creating something with my hands. Once a model is finished, it feels like it's over, and I'm eager to start working on a new one.

So, I was having a conversation with a friend today about how art is a very essential thing for humans, somewhat like pure expression of human spirit. Unfortunately, we tend to restrict human performers of art to only the very best. The people who become painters are the best at painting, the people who are musicians are the best at music, and so on. Project Trooper talked about participatory music, where the audience is part of the music as well. It's just a thing that people do, as opposed to being an exclusive stage for professional musicians. My friend brought up this study, which I thought was really interesting. In an Indigenous community in Peru, music-making is highly participatory, and an ethnomusicologist conducted a study there once. Any male community member is welcome to perform with pipes or flutes with his community, and anyone is welcome to dance. One time, when the author of the study was at one of these events, there were two folks from the community who performed with extremely out-of-tune flutes, but it seemed like everyone was having fun. The author of the study, coming from a very different background from the West, was driven crazy by the out-of-tune flutes and tried to stand as far away from them as possible. He was shocked that none of the other players felt or gave any indication that anything was wrong, and no one discouraged their participation. Later, he had a conversation with another professional musician about how to tune, and even he said he cannot bring himself to point out that the flutes were out of tune. This is very different from the society I'm used to, where only the best are expected to perform, and music is often a way for the most talented people to showcase their talent. Since art is willing to grow to the human experience, isn't it better for music to be participatory? You should probably be more accepting of all skill levels taking part in art instead of just putting the best on a pedestal. On the flip side, I also think that there should be people pushing art to its boundaries, and of course, that can't be everyone. I just think, and my friend thinks too, that everyone should get a chance to participate in music, just like that community...and curve.

Today I was able to meet up with a friend that I hadn't seen in over ten years. Our time goes back to when we worked together for quite a while. We ended up losing touch after they moved away to another state. I tried to keep in touch with them over social media but I just lost contact after awhile. 

In any case, I happened to be out shopping at the mall and happened to stumble across someone who looked somewhat familiar to me. I went a bit closer towards their direction and got a better look. I asked, "Bobby, is that you?" He responded with a yes and then immediately he remembered who I was. We embraced and gave out a big laugh. It was so funny seeing him after all this time. 

We began to talk a bit and do some catching up. I had found out about why he was back in in the area and what he had been up to for all this time. I found out that he was visiting his parents and that he was out with his family that day. I couldn't believe that we would be able to see each other in such a random way. 

We decided to meet up for lunch the next day and just talk a bit more about how life had gone up to this point. We really got a kick out of seeing the changes that have taken place in each of us.

I'm going to tell you about the time I moved when I was eight, maybe nine, possibly only seven. I think it was in elementary school, and that's what got me into reading and learning. I had just started school, maybe finishing first grade in the middle of second grade. We moved homes, still in the same city, but I didn't know any kids in the new neighborhood. My friends weren't there anymore. Eventually, I did make a few friends, but in the beginning, there wasn't much to do outside because I didn't know anyone. I was at home a lot. We happened to have a bunch of books at home, including random encyclopedia books, so I decided to start reading them. They were fun, and I liked learning about things around the world. Since it wasn't through school or forced on me, I thought it was fun. If I forgot stuff, it was okay. Unlike school where you had to remember everything or try. So, accumulating knowledge was fun, and I loved throwing it out randomly. I always obsessed over it and eventually started reading stories and fiction too. These days, I haven't been reading as much, but I still love learning things. It stuck with me and helped me in school. Later in higher classes, I would come across the same things I had seen in encyclopedias before, making school much easier. My teachers are always kind of surprised that I've read something in some random, obscure book. That feeling of just learning things for fun and satisfaction is something I want to keep with me.

So here's something I wrote about Doors, but it's really sort of a metaphor for irreversible things. Imagine you're in the room, the kind of room which you never really think of leaving, and there's a door, though, that troubles you in this otherwise perfect room. You don't know what's on the other side - it might be paradise, it might be hell, it might be nicer than your room, or it might be worse. Do you take the door? The door turns out to be just a doorway with one side visible, and it looks like paradise. Since you can always return and everything will be exactly as it was before you left, you can choose to take the door, which seems like an easy decision. If the paradise outside is an illusion, you can return and there's a safety net, which is nice. So you could choose to take the door; not much can go wrong. Now suppose the door was made of wood, and there's now a real tangible door that you can't peek through, but you can still walk back if you take the door. You might enter paradise or you might regret your choice. So you take the door. Out of ground this choice isn't much harder - life in the room is nearly perfect, and would be at risk being thrust into hell for a chance of something better. But in the end, you know you can always come back, so you take the door. Now suppose the door is made of glass, and you can see the other side which is paradise. There's a lock, however, so if you leave the door, you will never return, and all you have is the vision through the glass. It's scary because it's permanent, but you also don't need to leave immediately. You can stay in your perfect room for however long you want, and then take the door. Now, suppose the door is made of metal, you can't see through it, and it will lock so you can only choose to exit and never return. The stakes are much higher, because you don't know what's beyond the door and you can never return. But you still have the option of waiting for long, spending your entire life in your perfect room until you have nothing to lose, and then taking the door. But now imagine you have to do the whole thing again, with all these different doors, but you only have one night to decide whether you take the door at all. If you want to, it might be the best decision you ever make or the worst one. Maybe you never know what you missed. I can't decide whether I want to take the door in that one.

Blue, today, I attended the first lecture of one of my classes this semester, which is quite fun. The class is about J.R.R. Tolkien, the famous author of The Lord of the Rings, who was also a great scholar of medieval literature, languages, philology, and stuff. He had conversations with friends like C.S. Lewis, who, at least in the beginning, was an atheist and didn't believe in the value of things like God and metaphysics, but he later converted. Today, we read a part of a poem written by Tolkien, which wanted to explain why metaphysics are important because C.S. Lewis thought metaphysics were just beautifully crafted lies without any truth in them. Tolkien's response was to compose a long poem about why metaphysics are useful. One part that particularly caught my attention was the beginning, where Tolkien describes a fictional character called Miso Metis, who doesn't believe in the value of metaphysics. He says the person looks at natural objects like trees and just labels them "trees" and walks across the Earth as though everything is determined mathematically, with atoms moving as expected and every outcome being predictable, as if the world is just code regimented in a way where destined atoms are each moment's flame. It's like a very lifeless worldview, in contrast with a different one in which he believes in a God and has a belief that there's some purpose beyond our comprehension, and God who made everything in the world. These are not merely just objects that work according to mathematical principles, but more than that. I think this struck me because, like the professor mentioned, MIT students tend to have this worldview, viewing the world as deterministic and treating life as sort of an optimization problem to get the maximum outcome. I don't think all MIT students are like this, but a subset does think like this. I disagree with that worldview. I agree with Tolkien that life is not just an optimization problem and that part of life is experiencing imperfections and decisions. But maybe that's just me. I'm not sure.

About a month ago I returned to doing something that I was very passionate about and loved to do. It had been about five years since I had last been a pool. 

Since I was about 8 years old I had been swimming competitively over the summer at my neighborhood pool, from there I swam for my high school team, and then around the same time I began swimming for a club team. Between morning practices before school and then practices after school as well as the occasional swim meets that took place throughout the week my schedule was booked. I would go to my club practices every Saturday meaning essentially I got one day off every week which was Sunday. 

When the season was up for high school swimming I would go on to continue swimming for my club and then during the summer I would do both club and swim for my neighborhood swim team. Swimming was my life. It was all I had known since I was 8 years old and when I was 18 I had to make the painful choice about whether or not I wanted to continue swimming in college. 

I ended up choosing having a social life over swimming to a lot of people's dismay. Towards the end of my high school career I was emotionally and physically drained and I felt like I just needed a break. So I went on to have a normal college life with no swimming involved. It was difficult. The guilt definitely took a toll on my subconscious. I would have dreams all the time about getting back into the pool and I wondered if I had made a mistake. 

I began to avoid pools at all costs and it wasn't until recently that I decided I was ready to get back into the water. A light that seemed to have dimmed inside of me was now brighter than ever and it just felt right and I've been doing it ever since.

Yeah, I've been reaching out to more people and seeing if I can talk to more people in this New York City and get to know more people around here. I had a dinner with a friend last week, which was really nice. It was really good to have common friends and then catch up. We had Korean food, which was really nice. And I think she is Chinese. I don't think she ever had Korean food, I don't know. It was very new for her, so it was really nice just to explore something new together. She's a master student, so she's still studying. That was interesting to hear what she's been doing and what? Yeah, I just graduated so I could see, I could see whatever she was going through, like how I was also going through the same things and how difficult it is to start studying again, and then be in this new space where you're supposed to perform so much, but then you're also trying to get somewhere. But it's also really confusing and scary. So I could empathize with that, I think. But then, yeah, it was interesting. I did feel like not heard in that whole conversation. It was very one way, she didn't ask a lot about me, which is fine. But it was like a network dinner, and not like "Oh, friend" kind of thing, which is also fine. I think not every person you meet is going to be your friend, but it was like a new thing to try, which was nice.

Hello. I was just going to say, ever since I was little, I enjoyed waking up and hearing birds singing. My mother knew every bird call and could identify every bird, tree, and flower indigenous to Virginia. I was always in awe of that. Since we've moved back here, I started doing ebird, which is an offshoot of the Ornithology Department at Cornell University. It's called ebird. It's basically trying to ascertain the number of migratory birds in a certain area at a certain time so they're able to go back for several years and look through to see what types of birds were coming through here, stayed here, and what is not so prevalent now. I am pleased to say, since doing it, I can recognize many calls. I can say, "Oh, that's a Cardinal." It's really fun. I have a crow that comes just about every day to eat peanuts. His name is Victor because of a vampire movie I saw once, and he looks real big and black. Anyway, it's just fascinating to me to watch them and to see all the colorful birds. Like I said, Cornell does a wonderful job. They have a great Ornithology Department. It's just something, excuse me, that I've always wanted to learn more about. Since I have started learning it, I've taken additional classes with the Ornithology Department and learned so much about identification. In my own yard, I have identified over 180 species and turned in over 5,000 daily sheets. I'm proud of that. It's given me a wonderful hobby. I just wanted to tell you about that. Thank you.

Okay. In other outings, in other sessions, rather, I have discussed that I didn't have a lot of friends my own age or in school because I was three years younger than my classmates and we weren't doing the same thing socially. Thank goodness there wasn't social media because I would have been in dire straits, but nonetheless, other than homework, it would have been great with all the internet and all that. But nonetheless, when I was growing up, it was true. I read most of the time and books were my friends. But at school, I didn't have a lot of close companions or acquaintances because they looked at me as someone rather odd. And in between being a bookworm, I was also very sick. I had lung disease since I was born, and so they weren't quite sure what category to put me in. So I didn't fit in any categories. So across the street from where my parents lived, a colonel and his wife moved in. Colonel from the Air Force. And they had traveled all over the world. And they brought with them a young girl they had adopted from Okinawa. And I want to tell you about her. Haysia Garrett was her name. And she was three years younger than my brother. She was a freshman when he was a senior in high school. And she was exotic and beautiful, a beautiful girl. And her parents, one thing, they dressed her very nicely, always looked put together and beautiful. And she befriended me. Her parents were very, very strict. They didn't allow her to socialize with the neighbors or any of the people around, much less date or, God forbid, a boy would come by. But anyway, I started going over to her house after school when she'd get home, and we just had the best time. She regaled me with stories about Okinawa and the foods that they would consume, which I was like, oh, wow, that's so exotic. And she told me this story: they were very poor. It was five girls, and their father, after World War II, he had been a profitable farmer. But after World War II, that was no longer viable. And so he would go out rummaging for stuff to sell and make money, he came across this big piece of metal. And he brought it back to the kitchen and he was trying to get scrap metal off of this big piece to sell for money for food and the like. And unbeknownst to him, it was an unexploded bomb of some sort. And by striking it with a hammer, it exploded, killing him instantly. The girls had various stages of injuries and stages of severity. Haysia, she had a mark on her arm with shrapnel in it on her forearm, looked almost like a vaccination used to look in your upper arm. And anyway, she told me about her sisters, and the only one I can remember is Hike Hume. But Haysia, she was just a wonderful friend to me, taught me so much about the world, and was kind and considerate to me, considering all that she had been through losing her family, moving to a strange country, learning English, and of course, the attitudes in the '60s. It was still "dap" that word was used and heard that frequently, and yet she managed to show kindness to a skinny little sickly kid. She didn't realize how much her kindness touched me and how it changed my whole trajectory in childhood, from being the outcast to feeling like I had a really special bond with someone and knowing that I could be a good friend to people and that I had something to offer them. She made me feel special. For that, I'll never forget Haysia and how beautiful she was and how she overcame so much. I loved her and I still do. Remember her quite fondly. She got married and we lost touch, but she's in my heart forever. Thank you.

Okay. Well, I told you about how I met my husband, right? I took my daughter to that concert in Atlanta. And anyway, I found out he was a metalhead, like heavy metal music - the lead guitarist and singer. And he just traveled all over the world and played. So, after we met, we started writing each other emails daily or we do direct messaging with hearts and all that. We talked for months from April until July, and I went to New York. He was still practicing well, rehearsing with his band, and we were working on material. But he was working as a session musician in New York. So he told me if I would come there and visit, ask me if I would come there and visit. So I went, and I decided to take an Amtrak because it's a 55-minute plane ride from Richmond to New York. So I said, "I want to be able to look out the window and see the countryside." But get there expediently, so I took the train. I was really nervous. It was like I didn't know what to expect because my children were, like, "Oh, go and have a great time? Go, have a great time." They were in college. They didn't care what I was doing. And one of my older sisters, she said, "Hope, he's not an axe murderer." And that pretty much sums up their relationship. Anyway, so I'm nervous and I get there, and I had to go to the bathroom really bad. So I went to the bathroom, and I was coming out, and he passed me. And I said, "Rolo," and it was him. So anyway, what happened was he had gone to the station, and I wasn't there. He assumed I didn't come. And when I came out of the bathroom and was looking for him, I assumed he didn't come. So anyway, we met. He was gorgeous with that hair. And we proceeded to do all the touristy things because I hadn't been to New York in years. Because I'd been going to work for a European company, so I went to Europe a lot. Anyway. The request I had made was: it was a blue Moon, it was the 31st of July. And I asked that we dance on the moonlight of a studio where they were rehearsing. And at midnight. And that request was granted. And he just proceeded to tell me if I would move up and be with him, I could do whatever I wanted to. So to me, someone who had restrictions for so long on a set schedule and everything that I was to do for the day would be a laundry list, it sounded wonderful. Totally anathema to what I was doing because I was so controlled about everything. And so, we just had the best life in New York. We would take his rehearsal spaces in Bayonne, New Jersey, which is about 9 miles outside of Manhattan. And we would take the water taxi. And on my way to work every day, I would pass the Statue of Liberty, and it just felt I just felt really happy during that time. The people were a different story because in Virginia, everybody's "Hi, how are you? La, la, la, la, la," really nice. Well, in Central Virginia, no, Northern Virginia is more rough, not rough but they're not as kind and gentle people, anyway. Well, that might be an oversimplification, I guess because there are so many more people and the traffic and all that, you get to be more uptight. So anyway, things that happened in New York was I remember the first time I peed. That day when I got there. I moved. This was in October, from July until October. I would go every week and visit him, fly or drive. One time. And that was the last time. Anyway, I kept coming to visit and things got really well. We just got on so well from the onset. So anyway, the first day I moved in, October 13. I don't remember the year anyway. He told me to call and order. He gave me a number of this great shop, he said, Italian place. Get a couple of salads. So I called, and the gentleman answered the phone and said, "What do you want?" And I hung up the phone immediately because I thought I'd bothered him and it was a place of business. He didn't mention that or anything, so I called back and ordered subsequently. But anyway, it was just such a melting pot of cultures and I loved it. I walked everywhere. I didn't have to drive. I hate driving. And it was just my daughter would come, and we'd walk down Broadway. And on Saturdays, we'd go to all the little food places and get something from all these different cultures. And we would just try different dishes, and we'd go home with all our purchases and have a feast. And then we'd go to the rehearsal space, and she loved my husband from the start. My son was more standoffish, but he didn't come visit us. But when we moved back here, after we lived in Florida, then it's not his father. So his father's dead, and he can't replace him. So I'm rambling. But anyway, I just wanted to tell you I moved up to New York, and it was like my eyes were wide open. And it was so nice to be exposed to that. Because so many people here, they are born and raised in a town, and they never leave it. I mean, they go on vacation and whatnot. But they never experience any different cultures or different life. And I just can't understand it. But anyway, we danced on them. I told you about his dancing. About. And we just had a great time in New York, and it's a wonderful city. The museums are great. The Met, The Guggenheim. It's just a wonderful place. You have to be careful, like in every big city. But it's definitely an eye-opener. Someone from a more provincial point of view. So even though I'd been there and all over the world living there, it was a whole different experience. And I had so much fun. So that's my story.

An event that was memorable to me recently is getting a new kitty cat. She was a gift for my seven year old son from his father, he cleared it with me first whether he could get the cat as we already have two. I initially was going to say no, but then he told me that it was a Rag Doll kitty, and I had read a lot about how awesome that breed of cat is. The fact that it was a pure bred cat changed my mind as to whether we should get it. My first two cats are rescues, from a kill shelter and from a vet's office, I told myself I had saved two already and I can give this one a good home too. 

I told him yes, then we had to almost a month for her to be ready to come to our house. When my ex finally brought her over I had no idea how quickly I would fall in love with her. She's the cutest, fluffiest, little kitty ever, and her personality is so easy to like. She's sweet and cuddly, purrs as soon as you touch her or pick her up, and she looks so happy to be pet. 

She's also super playful, pick up a toy and she comes running and pounces on it, her favorite toys have feathers on them. She runs and jumps through the air so comically that you can't help but laugh at her antics. 

She's made a huge impact in my home, the other two kitties have been very accepting of her, after the first day hissings. I love my first two cats to pieces, but neither one of them is a lap kitty. New kitty loves to curl up on my lap and be pet. It makes me so happy to have a kitty that likes to snuggle and be close. 

I'm very happy that I now have three cats in my home, so is my son, as he likes to say he's a crazy cat boy.

Okay. I just wanted to talk about my mother, the coolest lady ever. We had like two families in my house. My mother had me very late in life. My sisters are 20 years older than me. My brother was eleven, so I was the youngest. When parents say they don't have a favorite, they always do, and you can't help it. It's human nature. I was my mother's favorite, and I'm sorry, my sisters really resent that. We just meshed, were the same. Anyway, she took good care of me when I was a child and sick all the time. She loved me unconditionally. When I got older and could drive, it was like we've got freedom. My father worked all the time as a chemical engineer, even renovating Victorian houses for my sister in Charlottesville on his vacation. My mother never got to do anything unless I took her. We'd make events out of the silliest things, like mock pina coladas at the car wash. We had wild times doing crazy things. We shared a love of hot, spicy foods. She was the best mom ever. She saved money, very frugal from the Depression. She was so much fun, we had the best time together. I could tell her anything, she would tell me anything. She died when I was in my early 40s, miss her every day. For the longest time, I would try to call her every day. She never got to meet my husband, who I met the same year she died. I feel like she sent him to me because I wouldn't get along so well without her. Gregory is outgoing, wonderful, total opposite, but we mesh perfectly. I think she sent him to me. I met him a month after she died. That was the story about my mother, Elsie, who always likened it to the cow, so I called her Elise. Gina and Elise had some thrilling little adventures here.

First off, it might sound rambling, but it's a means to tie it all up. We became tired of the same old routine in New York. Working, going to the studio, it became hectic with my four-hour commute. So, we decided to move down to Florida where my husband's mother and stepfather lived on a farm inland. They had ten acres with animals. We stayed with them and decided to get a place at the beach. The beach was only 35 to 40 minutes away and we would go there every Saturday and Sunday. The water was clear and we enjoyed the seafood joints there. We were happy, but I contracted a soil-based disease due to my inherent asthma. I had seizures and was in ICU for 45 days. My husband helped me with IVs at home. I would sleep on the sofa with our five rescue cats surrounding me. They seemed to be protecting me. One day, I felt someone rubbing my forehead like my mother used to when I was sick. It was a comforting presence that continued even after I found out an older lady had passed away in the house. My husband teased about the ghost and a glass panel on the stove broke as he said the ghost didn't like him. We moved the following fall because of the burden and strange occurrences. It was nice to come back to Virginia. Whether it was a ghost or just a feeling from my NDEs, it was a calming and reassuring presence in Florida. Thank you.

So, okay, I started this project talking about my brother and I'm going to end it that way. Okay, so my brother went through basic training at Fort Benning, then to Fort Polk in Louisiana, back to Fort Benning in Georgia, and then back to Fort Polk. He was doing well and was eventually promoted to Sergeant. He was always real fraternal and a natural leader. So anyway, he became a Sergeant and was leading his troops. From what I recall, it was a late fall almost Christmas time and it was cold and brisk. I remember walking home from school. I had the type of mother who every day when I got home, she would have something baked, like gingerbread. Oh, the house smelled heavenly. This one particular day, I come home and I open the front door expecting wonderful aromas but instead there was silence. The house was dark. I was calling for my mother and walked to my parents' bedroom. There she was, looking small, sitting on the edge of her bed by a window looking out. There was a letter next to her that had fallen to her side. I said, "Mama." She didn't move, so I picked up the letter and it was from the Department of the Army. My brother had stepped on a landmine and was being airlifted to Walter Reed Army Hospital in D.C., about 90 minutes away. So she was in shock and I had to comfort her. But I wanted to mention that he survived, if he had been 1 cm closer, he would have been blown to bits. The guy behind him got shrapnel which almost blew his knee off. He was never the same after that. But I loved my brother dearly. He subsequently passed, never the same once he came back from that war experience. He didn't mind shooting the enemy when they were firing at him, but he couldn't kill an old man in a village because he thought of our grandfather. He told me that story, I loved my brother.

Back in first grade, there was this kid who moved to our district, name was Zoe, and she was pretty headstrong in what she would do. Like she would do it fully, without any hesitation or concern about consequences. I remember one art project we were doing where we had to paint snowmen. We had to make the hat black, the nose orange, and everything else was to be white. Zoe accidentally spilled a drop of black onto the white of her snowman's body and turned it into a coat. I thought that was super cool, so I did that to mine as well. Eventually, the teacher kind of got mad at us and washed ours off so we could repaint it. I wasn't too grappy about it, but Zoe just didn't seem to care. In that moment, I learned that if you're going to do something, at least be fully confident in it and don't be too affected if the results aren't what you want or expect. You do something, own up to it and accept what happens as a result. I carry that on today. Now she's very successful, on a study abroad program that's super selective in Japan, doing exactly what she wanted to do from the beginning. No one's told her no or told her to do something else. She just keeps on going. I really admire that about her.

About six months ago I entered a custody battle after my partner admitted to cheating, then subsequently ran off with our child. I had just started a new job, so I had to sell a majority of my belongings and dip into my savings to pay for representation. In the process, given I had to take time off from my new job, I wound up being let go even though I was told by my supervisor that it was okay for me to take time off from work so soon given the importance of the situation. 

I knew I wouldn't be able to keep up with my overly expensive rent, so I wound up breaking my lease early and living in an Airbnb for a month thanks to my savings. This gave me time to look for a new job and actual apartment to start over in. 

I wound up losing the custody battle in the process because I could no longer afford to pay my attorney. If it wasn't for the vast majority of online jobs available today and the fact that I didn't sell one of my laptop computers, I probably would've been out on the street considering everyone in my family has passed, and a majority of my close friends now live on the other side of or outside the country. 

Needless to say this has been an eye opening experiencing, and it just goes to show you that life is so unpredictable. Here I was comfortable in my career path only to have an unforeseeable event turn entire life upside down. I've always been a humble person, but when you go from eating at five-star restaurants daily, to eating free Dunkin' Donuts for a month straight it really makes you realize what's really important in life. 

All and all this experience has taught me a lot. Not to be jaded, but to really cherish and be thankful for the little things that you do have (like your health) instead of taking things like a hot shower or clean water for granted. 

I honestly don't know where this journey will take me next, but I'm honestly thankful that I at least have a roof over my head while I fight to get my life back to what it was. "Just because you've found yourself in the gutter, that doesn't mean you have to stay there." I once remember my grandfather saying those words to me when I was a child... And they've been my motivation throughout this entire experience. Both the good and the bad.

So I have some friends from a while ago, and we used to be really close together and we spend a lot of time. We would chat, we would hang out, we would go do stuff together. And there was a pandemic in the middle, so I wasn't really able to have a lot of contact with them. And the few that I did have contact with, it was mostly like around school, things like, "Oh, what's the homework? Did you finish the homework? Do you have the answers to the homework?" So I kind of left contact with a lot of them. And then right when everything was opening back up again, I chose to take a quarter off because there were no classes being offered, and I didn't want to spend money on classes that I wasn't really needing to take. By the time everything got open, people were fully back to doing stuff outside and meeting up, I had graduated and left. And then I moved to a different school because I started my PhD. I have some friends over there, but I've only known them for a short period of time, so I'm not super close with them. And then this summer, I came back home, hopefully hoping that I could meet up with the friend pool I had in undergrad and it just didn't happen, and it really hurt because I lost the opportunity to really make friends and maintain friends because of a pandemic that was outside of my control. By the time I was able to go back, I had to leave. Now I'm in this spot where I don't really have a lot of close people to talk with, so I'm kind of sitting by myself, and it's really lonely.

So, yeah, so maybe I don't know when I could say this story started, but I guess I could say it started nine years ago when I was in elementary school and middle school, I played the violin in an orchestra and then I decided to quit. I decided to play by myself and practice, but I just couldn't keep it up. This year, I decided I was going to do it when I was planning to move to Boston, make that one of my goals of things that I wanted to do when I got here, if it was available, and it was. I met up with a teacher, played something for her on the first day, and then told her I'd take two weeks to practice before starting up the lessons. The problem was I only practiced once. However, I'm meeting her day after tomorrow, so I practiced today as well. As I was practicing today, I remembered she was teaching me all these things about holding my bow. So, I just ended up walking around my room practicing that exercise she gave me. I kept thinking about how when I go in there, she'll either be impressed with my improvement or I'll have to admit I haven't practiced much. It's interesting when you have goals you are working towards, but it can be difficult to find the motivation to actively work towards them.

Yeah, let me think. A brief story, I guess, is today in my workplace they were holding a class. I wasn't planning to take the class or do anything. They were like, "Oh, you should come.
