You should attend," just to have a presence. So I was like, "Okay, I'll try to be there." I go in, and then they actually had me participate in the class. I'm there, introducing myself, then they sorted me into a group for the activity. It was really interesting. In a different circumstance, the people in the class would be my peers because I graduated college last year. I could theoretically have gone into a master's and be doing a master's right now. They're master students, probably similar age to me, maybe some older. They were kind of looking to me for some sort of guidance or asking me questions. Some of the people seemed a little uncertain, then they would be like, "Oh, is that right? Does that sound good?" and kind of direct some of their questions and stuff to me. It was just very interesting to think about how sometimes, regardless of age, your life stage can be very different from someone. Your maturity or self-understanding kind of changes based on the environments that you're used to being in.

But yeah, so this is a story kind of about my own failings, I guess, and this kind of relates to something that we talked about before. You asked me how am I going to make sure that I get the advice and mentorship and stuff that I need. Actually, I have made progress on that because my work offers a mentorship program for people who are working. I met with someone today to find a mentor, and she said that she's going to try and get me connected with a buddy - like a buddy mentor who can kind of help me, but that's beside the point, that's not the story.

So basically, for the past five months or so, I have a particular friend that I haven't been talking to as much. I've been kind of not constantly worried about it, but I think about it sometimes and just, I don't know, just think about her. I wasn't sure because I thought she hadn't texted me, and I wasn't sure if I should text her if I should make that effort. Until last week, I actually texted her and I asked her like, "Hey, have you forgotten about me?" And she texted back immediately. She's like, "What? I've been thinking about you. You never responded to my message or like my messages." She sent me a screenshot, and I realized that she had tried to text me, but it went to the wrong number or went to my old number that I had before.

And so then that just led to me thinking a lot about how I want to deal with my anxiety around friendships because I feel like there are certain friendships that I really value and certain friends that I really value and I don't want to lose. I generally have pretty good instincts for things like that. But then, I will have that instinct, but then something else will happen that is kind of an issue or like a worry for me. I don't know exactly how to address it or how to fix it. So then I start to question whether or not my judgment actually was good, whether that person actually was a good friend. Or I'll say, "We're a good friend for the time, but maybe not anymore." And we'll just, I don't know, just kind of like spiral into worrying about it and being like, "Okay, fine. The relationship is over. Whatever. I'll just have to let it go," but then I can never just let it go so I don't know why I even have that thought to begin with.

But yeah, so I talked to that friend today, and it was just so nice. There are some friends I talked to and I leave feeling kind of off or like, "What was the point?" or whatever. But this friend has never been the case, and I just feel like I really need to find a way of actually dealing with this problem that I have so that it won't just continue to get in the way of friendships that I really care about.

My wife went to Germany this past spring for a study abroad program through her school. We live with another roommate who was here with me while my wife was away. One night I got a phone call from my landlord asking me if she can come over in the morning and perform some long needed maintenance on the bathroom. I'm usually a night person but I set my alarm for 8 AM, excited for our shower to finally be repaired. I always keep my phone on silent and when my alarm goes off at 8 AM I notice I received a text message in the middle of the night from my roommate. The text read: "lol who's the drunk snoring guy?" I thought nothing of the message, seeing as we live close to downtown in a city that has a huge homeless crisis. Many nights I'm awakened by people screaming as they walk past my house. I assumed a drunk guy fell asleep outside the house and she could hear him snoring from her room. 

Before the landlord arrives, I need to move my cat's kitty litter from the bathroom and bring it upstairs. I walk down the stairs and notice around the corner there are dirty shoes hanging off the couch like somebody is laying there. I peak around the corner and what do you know it's the snoring drunk guy. Panic flushes over me as I realize that's not somebody my roommate invited in. I look at the doors, both are locked. No windows are broken. I go through all these different scenarios in my mind about who the person could be. Maybe it's an old tenant who knows my wife and still has a key. Maybe it was the maintenance guy that'd be helping my landlord that morning and he got here too early and decided to take a nap. 

I walk back up the stairs and wake up my roommate telling her I have no idea who the drunk snoring guy is. She's just as startled as me, assuming the guy was a friend of mine, but also much braver as she grabs an empty wine bottle next to her in case she needs to bludgeon anybody. She gets up in the sleeping guy's face and wakes him up with questions about who he is and why he's here. He looks just as startled as the both of us. Apparently, he came in through the kitchen window in the middle of the night, drunk as hell, thinking it was his friend's(our back neighbor's) house. He apologizes profusely and is super sweet and tells us he did this before at another neighbor's house.

Yesterday, I heard that one boy told my daughter to prove that she had a $1 million bill, and if she couldn't, she had to pay $5. It isn't appropriate for that to happen at school. I raised my concern in an email to her teacher last night and met with her this morning. She assured me that she will talk with those kids and let me know what she finds out, mentioning there might have been a misunderstanding between the students. However, I heard about the incident yesterday from another parent whose child was at the scene with my daughter, so from my perspective, it happened like that. Anyway, I'll wait for the teacher's response.

Regarding the $1 million bill, it's fake money. Lena, my daughter, thinks it's real money given by a random, very generous person she got the bill from during Christmas on the street, so she believes it's real. This situation is a little complex because she doesn't want to admit it's a lie. She believes it is real, even though it's not. But she doesn't want to say she didn't have the bill because she does have it. Let's see. The most important thing is that school must be a safe place where children can learn with respect to each other, and no kids should take money from other students for any reason. I'm upset and worried, but I'm heartened to hear that my daughter's friends were there with her and supported her when she was too scared to take action, eventually reporting it to yard duty. I'm grateful she had such nice friends.

Yesterday I got to go the the capital of my state. I was impressed by the things that I saw, yet still disappointed. It was interesting to see the place we play baseball and some of the famous architecture that we have. I have also struggled with ageism in the work place and got a really good glimpse of it yesterday which was so disappointing. 

We were outside walking around at noon when all the office workers come out for lunch. The area we were in only had 1 or 2 people out of hundreds that were above the age of 30. I could not believe it. There were people everywhere and yet they were so young. This is not fair at all. We have worked just as hard to get our education and work experience, yet we are being pushed out of working for being older workers. 40's is now considered an older worker!. 

Anyway, it was nice to get away for a while and spend some time with a friend. We had to wait 3 hours. So we had plenty of time to see the sites and experience out state capital fully. I was impressed by how big everything is in the big city. I saw magazine covers, people working out right in the middle of the area. Scooters. Rentable bikes. Food everywhere.

"Yeah. So, I was playing tennis with my friend this weekend, she just had a baby, like a month ago, which is insane," she shared. "She's super funny," she added, recounting the story of her friend getting to the hospital with her husband. "Oh, man, it was just so funny." "But I can't believe that it's only been a month and she's playing tennis," she mused. "I thought that was pretty impressive that she's able to get back." "Her and both of her husband are our friends," she continued, "they're both pretty funny." "So, it's very interesting to see them both trying to get out and play tennis as much as possible, and then they have to switch off watching their baby," she chuckled. "Oh, man." "But she was telling me about how she's a lot more chill now because she has this kid," she continued, "mentally, she has changed her perspective," she added. "I'm definitely have a different mental state now," she quoted her friend, "which I guess makes sense." "It's pretty cool to have somebody finally that's had kids so you can understand what's going on," she reflected. "Because up until now, I never had any friends that had kids," she admitted. "And I haven't really been around babies." "It's going to be a funny little kid," she predicted, "really smart parents." "So, it'd be kind of cool to be around."

Well, like I said, we're watching my grandparents' dog and it just reminded me of when I had my dog when I was in 8th grade. I had him for two years, he was a little pug, very cute. My mom got him for free from one of her students who bred the dogs. We got Zazu because we had Simba, my other dog, so we kept with the Lion King theme. He was very hyper, but he was inbred which we didn't know. Zazu had a condition where he had a lot of air pockets around his heart and in his stomach, and it was very uncomfortable for him. He always tried to eat something to make himself feel better. He was always running around really fast, just a little uncomfortable, but he was my dog. He was so cute and he loved me and he was very smart. But it just reminded me of whenever we had to let him go. I was coming back from a baseball game and started getting panicked because I couldn't find him, he liked to hang out in my grandparents' closet. I called his name for like three or four minutes, and finally I heard his dog tags rattle, his collar. He was trying the entire time to get up, and I felt so bad because I couldn't find him and he was trying to get up. Finally, he did, and he was so weak. Very sad. But he was a good dog, a very good dog.

Well, I'm really excited because Thursday, I'm leaving to go on vacation for Portugal. But I just picked up a new job right before I left, and my regular work picked up a lot more than I'm used to as well, so it's been a little bit stressful trying to keep up with both. But one is like super fulfilling and really exciting, but it doesn't pay a lot. And then the other one is up and down with good and lots of things to do, and then at times, nothing. But there's really not a whole lot of career growth there or opportunities for growth. It's just kind of a lot of hustling, so I'm just trying to work into being able to do both. But I'm definitely working a little more. And so what I'm trying to do is tell myself that I need to take a break whenever I go to Portugal. Although I'm like super excited about this new job and really want to dive into it, it's pretty cool. It's like a lot of 3D modeling for coastline that then hurricane modelers and physicists can take their data and actually apply it to a 3D model. So I'm really excited about it. Most people there are really nice. I think the engineers are a little-- there's a couple that are a little like. They're a little not sure about me because I think a lot of times people think that design and art is trivial, when in actuality, it's just as cognitive and just as helpful. And just like I respect their profession, it would be nice if they would respect mine and see the value that I could bring to the table. I mean, it's kind of funny. A lot of their visualizations are just like so lost without their words, and I don't think they realize that they could create a better image that is more communicative to audiences that aren't familiar with statistics and modeling, and natural language processing. And this tiny difference that looks really tiny - it's like maybe you're using the wrong visualization, but anyways, I don't know, I'm really excited about my job, but it's also definitely requiring me to be a little more organized. Which is good. I think it's a good challenge for me. I tend to be all over the place and hopefully this will help give me some structure because I have more things to do. So I'll be a little more responsive to my time, or careful with my time, and actually plan it out instead of wasting it.

Yeah, so it was my friend's birthday this weekend and it was very fascinating. I have a friend who was my sister's best friend in high school, and she has three siblings, and they're all interesting. But I met her older brother, whom I'd known for a year now, and he was like way older than me, like seven years. I went out with them last weekend, and it ended up in this really weird situation where he's like a 40-year-old guy who can't handle his emotions, and somehow I ended up being a little bit of a counselor to him and mediating him and his sister's fight. This past weekend, his little brother, whom I was friends with, was in town for my friend's birthday, and it was just interesting because they were talking about me and I was a little uncomfortable about that. They both need a lot of therapy, I think, and need to just get a handle on their own emotions and boundaries. They apparently were trying to get my number, and I made a joke that I'm going to have to start charging him for asking advice on things. But it's just a little strange and I thought I was kind of flattered about the older brother being interested in talking to me, I guess, and saying nice things. At the end of the night, his little brother that I was friends with kind of brought it back into reality that I was like, "Oh no, this is how these brothers act. There is no exception. This guy's probably being nice because I was being nice to him." It was just very strange, yeah. I don't know, it made me uncomfortable.

So, yesterday was a bold and interesting, and somewhat intense day for me as I have been working on getting out of chronic isolation due to my complex trauma (Complex PTSD). I attended two events yesterday, one in person and the other online over Zoom. The in-person event was an art meet up group that I had attended once before, and yesterday was the second time I went. There were more people than last time and we were sort of packed which made me anxious due to my social phobia. However, I was able to ground myself and enjoy the event doing art with other artists. The second event was a Zoom call with a pagan spirituality class where I shared stories about my own spirituality and overall enjoyed it. Despite my insecurities, I felt like I contributed to the discussion and the organizer was appreciative. This level of social participation felt more intense than anything I've experienced since the pandemic and even back in college. The feeling I had at the end of the day was weird and unlike any burnout or fatigue from social interactions I had experienced before. It felt like overstimulation and was quite new and intense, which made it hard for me to sit still. I stayed up late at night unable to sleep, worrying that this feeling might discourage me from future social interactions. However, I am proud of myself for taking steps to battle isolation and heal from past trauma.

Today, I got a lot of compliments. I got back home just now, took a back to my apartment, and there's like a giant mirror in front of the elevators. I entered the apartment building, walked to the mirror, and saw there's a white chair facing the mirror. I thought it might be a property of the apartment and someone might put it there for a purpose. I just went to the chair, put my bag on there, and posted and took a picture of myself. As I was doing that, a person walked out from behind my picture and then murmured something I don't quite remember what exactly. I think he said, "Hi" or something. Then, I took my bag off the chair and the man went and grabbed the chair and I said thank you to him. At first, I thought maybe he might be like using the chair before and now he's returning the chair to its original location. I was confused for a few seconds. Then, I realized, "Oh, that chair could be his. He might be moving in or moving out." I was using the chair to pose like someone else's chair. I feel quite embarrassed. And I think it's funny at the same time.

Yesterday evening, I went to dinner with a friend who I last connected with a few months ago, Shuzian. We got to know each other through a common friend of ours. Shuzian helped me take care of my cat when I was on a gap year and not in the US, which was super nice of her. We've only met each other three times in total, so we don't know each other that well. In the past week, I have been feeling lonely and thinking about who I could reach out to. Shuzian came to mind, so I asked her to hang out, grab dinner, and go to her home to see her cat. It went better than expected, even though she unexpectedly brought her husband to dinner. Normally, I would feel socially anxious if someone I don't know showed up abruptly, but somehow, I was able to remain relatively calm. There were moments of awkwardness and not knowing what to say, but overall, the conversation went quite well. Shuzian even suggested hanging out again, which is a nice change for me because in past friendships, I've been the one who initiates events. After I told Shuzian that my friends were busy, she said she would be super happy to meet up again and play some board games. She even suggested bringing her friends over, which was super nice. In many of my recent friendships, there hasn't been a suggestion of continuing the relationship. It's nice that Shuzian suggested it, and I feel hopeful that a continuous relationship can develop between us.

Recently, I was the Maid of Honor in my best friend's wedding. This was a very important day. I had never been in a wedding, let alone the Maid of Honor. I had a lot of responsibilities and was very nervous about walking down the aisle. I know that everyone is looking at the bride but I was still anxious about having eyes on me even for a few seconds. 

We started our day early in the morning with coffee and hair and makeup. We got our hair and makeup done by professionals and it felt very special. My best friend and I chatted about how today was going to be life-changing. I was super excited for her and her husband-to-be. 

The time came for the ceremony and I walked down the aisle before my best friend. I watched her walk down and had to hold back tears and ugly crying. I took her bouquet when she took the hand of her soon to be future husband. I listened to their vows and I remember how happy they both were. 

The time came to exchange rings and say "I do." I handed her her new husband's wedding band and it was a very special moment for all of us. It was the most beautiful wedding I have ever been to.

I thought about this storage day because I'm making our meal plan for next week so that we can get organized and do grocery shopping. Meal planning and things like that have just become more of like a chore to me. When I was little, growing up, we didn't have cable, just basic cable that you get for free. PBS was one of those channels. I started watching Julia Child's Cooking Show on PBS when I was like eight or nine years old. I would watch it every chance I could get when it came on, that and Bob Ross, Painting Happy Little Trees. I was always fascinated by the recipes she made. They looked so good and different. So I started cooking for my family when I was about twelve years old. I never made anything super fancy like Julia Child's stuff, but I always felt like Julia Child when I was cooking. After school, I graduated and went to a traditional college. I ended up getting my degree in business. It wasn't until after I graduated, or was about to graduate, that I realized you can go to culinary school. There are many other options out there. I applied for a culinary institute and got in, but the tuition was really high. I had student loans from my traditional college and going into more debt was scary to me. Fast forward years later, now I have two kids. I still enjoy cooking, but it's more of like a chore now because we've got to cook meals for the kids. My oldest daughter was helping me one day and I told her I almost went to culinary school. She asked, "How come you didn't go?" I explained about money. She said, "But it's never too late, you can always go now." She's right, I could go now, but my responsibilities are different now. What a great attitude to have from the perspective of a seven year old. It made me proud and reflect. Even though I didn't go to culinary school, I enjoy cooking with my kids and teaching them. I hope they find a love for the things I enjoy as well.

Okay, so I wanted to talk about the last two weeks. It's been really busy at work and I'm in a very interesting work situation right now. I've had the opportunity to step away from my normal job to do a fellowship program, which is really cool. I started this fellowship program back in April and it was supposed to be five months. When my five months came to an end, I approached the team about staying a little bit longer to provide some continuity. I got approval to stay for another cohort of this fellowship program, which is really exciting. I have a new coworker and we're supposed to be working together to accomplish all these tasks we've been given. Lately, I've been feeling a little overwhelmed because there's a lot going on and I'm frustrated that this other person isn't helping out as much as they should. I feel like they just lean on me to drive the train, even though we're teammates. We should be doing things together, not just relying on me for approval. So I've been really frustrated and overwhelmed, it's getting me down. I did take some time off, so I'll be off in the next three days, which will be nice to just take a break and clear my head. But I'm just kind of bummed out because of it.

But I guess I just wanted to think through something, I feel like I'm at a weird spot in my life. I think 23 was such a weird year for me, a lot of character growth. I never liked the number 23, always associate it with a weird vibe. Since the pandemic started, it felt like a lot of chaos, a lot of reshifting of priorities. From September 2022 to this year, last year was just a lot of sadness. I got COVID, and then I got sick so often. The last half of being 23 was so much better, solo traveled that forced me to do things on my own. Now I'm job hunting, realizing the limitations of not driving. For my career, I also have hard feelings on how important it is to focus on your career because I kind of don't care. But then I kind of need to feel secure. With my birthday coming up, it makes me wonder what the next year will be like. I feel like I'm in a better place to make decisions for myself. I know I have my friends and family to support me, which makes it better. So I think I'm being set up for a better experience for turning 24. Definitely 23 was a year full of chaos, growth, and reprioritization of my life. So maybe 24 will be better.

I wanted your advice about the thing I shared in the session. I guess I just feel weird about the whole situation. I told you where I went to my friend's birthday party dinner thing and I'm kind of part of the family, but kind of not. The brother is part of the family, but out of touch with what's been happening. It makes me feel weird because I know what's been like. The stories the brother didn't hear about or know, I had already heard or was familiar with. So it felt weird to be in this insider knowledge. Dang. I think I just feel weird about today and wanted to talk it out because I don't know how to process. It just felt awkward, the whole interaction. I don't know how awkward anyone else felt, but it felt weird that the celebration wasn't really just about her, but more about her brother. The other weird part was that the brother's fiance didn't remember me. I had red hair, but pretty much the same face. I was like, Girl, how do you not remember me? We met multiple times. It was awkward. I think today's close family event was more awkward for me, because I don't know my place. It's just weird.

Okay, so I'm in between a couple of stories to talk about. But I guess the one that's on top of my mind right now is related to birthdays. So, yesterday, I got processing feelings or rethinking things. For my birthday, my friend named Michelle, we've been friends since we were like twelve or 13. We had an interesting friendship development. We've been friends for a long time. Usually, my friends don't really get me anything for my birthday, unless it's like a birthday party, but even then not all the time. That's mostly because we all kind of grew up poor, and we're still kind of poor. So, I guess I just wanted to think through how as we get older and get access to more money, how does that change the way we spend and relate to each other. So, that's what's been on top of my mind because when I think about gifts or presents my friends have given me, it's always been something small, like a card or if they made something for me. We went out to eat someplace really cheap because we all really did not grow up with money, like low income. I've always been hesitant with gifts. Like gifts are not one of my love languages. I feel like because it's always been so hard with money growing up, it's hard for me to be comfortable spending a lot of money on someone or at least someone without them needing it. It's hard for me to give gifts that are valued a lot because I never really grew up with much. I feel weird when people give me gifts a lot of the time. I like the idea of receiving things. But when they're expensive, I'm kind of like, oh my God, why do they spend this much on me? My version of expensive is different than other people's version of expensive because I grew up poor. So, basically, my friend Michelle, we've been friends for a long time. We both grew up poor and now she has a higher-paying job and treats me out. I'm surprised and thankful. I'm also wondering what would my expectations of presence be if I hadn't grown up low income. I see that she's making more money and willing to treat me out. It makes me wonder how would I be thriving if I wasn't in survival mode. That's been on my mind. When I was making good money, I would treat people out, mostly at diners where everyone's meal is under $10. Or I would buy random things, mostly food related. I see the ways that I gave back and it's kind of nice to be on the receiving end. Now my friend is increasing in economic status, and she's also giving back. So, yeah, that's been on my mind. When I get another full-time job that pays me more than minimum wage, I wonder how I am also willing to give back to my friends and family. So, yeah, that's my story.

Okay, I had a dream recently about Salem, Massachusetts, because I don't know why it's the top of my head, but I did travel there one weekend when I was still in college and it took like 2 hours and a half by train, but commuter rail. So we had to swap and I made it to Salem, Massachusetts, which I've always wanted to go. I guess I've just been thinking about how much of a tourist trap it actually is. It's definitely not a place I want to visit anytime soon unless I was going with someone who's never been. I had a dream that reminded me of that experience and so I want to talk about haunted houses and horror, like horror, yeah, I guess. Now that Halloween is approaching us. So my sister, one of my sisters, really likes Halloween. And I was always kind of ambivalent to it, but I started thinking about all the times I accidentally got into a haunted house. The first time ever was in Salem, Massachusetts. So my friend and I decided to do a day trip and we were like, okay, we're going to go. I bought tickets to a museum, okay. I bought like tickets to the wax museum. And then I bought tickets to this haunted house, but actually I had no idea. I don't like haunted houses. I don't like being purposely scared. I feel like the world is scary enough. Why would I enact that on myself? So I try to avoid horror things. Then two years later, I bought tickets again to a haunted house by accident. Yeah. Well, actually later that year, my house floor at Wealthy became a haunted house. So if I wanted to get through my room, I had to go through the haunted house. And I was like, once I get in, I'm not coming out. So I had to walk through. Part of me wanted to do it, but this other part of me didn't. So this is the second time I accidentally walked into a haunted house. And it wasn't even that scary. They were on like a low budget for horror and it was just the fact that I knew they were trying to scare me freaked me out enough. Like I knew it was supposed to be scary and I was like, no, I'm out. I arrived in Switzerland and this person barely knew, I was like, sure, I'll travel with you. She's actually a good friend of mine now, but at the time I was just like, I don't know you, but we'll be travel buddies. And we worked out really well, travel buddies. She really wanted to go to London and I really wanted to go to Italy. So I was like, I'll go with you to London if you come with me to Italy. So then London was kind of our part to plan out because she really wanted to go and she was familiar with London and really liked the area. So as part of that, she was like, I really wanted to go to I think it was the Tower of Terrors, the London Bridge. The tombs, I think it was London Tombs. So it's basically like a part of the bridge where it's literally under an overpass of a bridge. And you go in and it's like a whole maze of horror. So they had like a doll house. They had a surgeon room. They had something with the pig at the end that freaked me out. So I was like, okay, I can do it. I'm brave. I got this. So then I was like, I just knew, don't be in the front, don't be at the end. So I tried my best to always be in the middle. And sometimes we got to break up our group and I was like, no, I'll do what it takes to shove my way so I am not at the end. And so I had my friend, literally the common denominator in all these stories, is like closing my eyes and running or like hiding behind someone. I wonder if that's a metaphor for my life, but at least for The London Tombs. Yeah, it felt like torture. Like I got to a point where I was like, I don't think I can do this any longer. I paid like £30 so I don't even know how much that was. But it was like £33, $35. And I was like, I have to stick it out because once I buy something, I'm like, I have to pull it through like already invested money in it. And I was hiding behind my friend a lot of the time and I was definitely closing my eyes all the time, but towards the end, once we got to the pig part, it was like a meat slaughterhouse and they had things hanging from the wall, they had blood everywhere. That and the doll room, I was just like, I need to leave. Like I'm out. I was barely holding it together. I really wanted to escape. I was already looking for emergency exits. I was like, I don't think I can do this any longer. Someone needs to pull the plug and it's going to be me. But right when I was at my end, at my wit's end and I was like, I can't do this any longer, I heard too, there's Swift music in the background. And I'm not much of a swifty, but I heard Taylor's up. And I was like, somewhere out there, there's an end to this tunnel. And on the other side, there's happy drunk people singing Taylor Swift. So then I was just like, I just had to keep closing my eyes and running through the tunnel, waiting for the swifty music to get louder and then finally we burst through the door and it opened up to a bar where everyone was screaming, like a Taylor Swift song. I don't remember what song it was. I just remember thinking, I am free. I can escape this and I don't have to be as scared anymore. So after that, I told my friend, I was like, Girl, we can't do this ever again. I was like, I'm done with horror stuff. Please let it be a chill rest of the evening. And I don't think it actually was because we ended up having, like, a problem with our flight. But at least I wasn't running away in fear with something chasing after me oinking. So those were three times accidentally walked into the haunted houses and decided to stick it through.

Okay, so I've been thinking about this for a day or so and just kind of trying to process my feelings around it or my new thoughts. My sister and I have been watching this K-drama, a Korean drama that I've already seen three times - in 2019, 2020, and now. My sister had never seen a K-drama before because she associates them with love, but this one was different. The main character, Jiho, described herself as slow and indecisive, which resonated with me. She was in her 30s and had never dated, which I could relate to. Watching her decisions unfold, I saw similarities in the ways we both chose paths and then suddenly changed directions. My sister even pointed out how I would react similarly to Jiho’s choices. I've always been told I'm made for something great, excelling academically and pursuing a prestigious university, only to quit my toxic job and travel. Now, I work at a bakery, rebuilding my skills for the future. Seeing Jiho make questionable decisions mirrors my own journey, and I find myself frustrated with where I am in life. It's interesting to see a character reflected on screen that's me and feel frustrated with them, even though I relate to their choices. It makes me question my own decisions and what I'm doing with my life.

I wanted to discuss my nephew's graduation from high school. He graduated from high school in June of 2019 and I was so proud because he is going to Princeton for college. He worked hard and was able to make it there through a combination of decent grades, a very good score on the SAT as well as working part-time for his father's business. He took the SATs twice. The first time he didn't do so well and scored a 1250. However the second time, he made a conscious effort to work on the weaknesses that he remembered and improved his score to a 1400. He is also an intern for his father's company, which is in the real estate business. He did the various odd jobs there where he cleaned up, made sure the pantry and other areas were well stocked and helped to input data into the company's systems. 

Part of the money that he saved was used to start up an IRA account. I work as a financial analyst and tried to show him what would happen if he used the power of compounding interest and how large he could grow his nest egg if he had 40+ years to invest. He ended up opening the account and buying 25 shares of Disney. 

When he graduated, we first went to a nice dinner at our local favorite Italian restaurant where he had his favorite meal, lasagna with a side of creamed spinach. After that we went to a movie. After that we went back home where we relaxed, played some board games and shared stories about the time that we went to college. It was, all in all, a very fun night.

All right, so I want to talk about when my friend visited. She was only here for a brief time, maybe two days, technically. It was my first time hosting a friend, and it was nice to be able to return the favor as I've had good experiences staying at other people's homes. My friend visited me because I was doing a master's program in Phoenix, and she lives in Boston. She came for class, so we only had about a day and a half to hang out. We ate a lot of good food, like street corn, mangoes, and carne asada fries. My goal was to show her unique Southwest food. She mentioned she only eats once a day, so I didn't know that and we ate a lot. We went out for drinks and visited murals in Phoenix. We also walked around the State Capitol and saw a movie being filmed about the founding of Arizona. It was cool to eat, take photos, and spend time with my friend in that way. I really like playing tour guide and sharing random facts about where I live. My friend enjoyed her visit and my family liked her too. She's welcome to come back anytime. That's what I did this weekend.

"Yeah, in this process of getting pulled into a different project, I started in a track with a lot of different people who I did not know about before, which are within my organization, per se," I shared. "One of the questions, it was pretty interesting to meet that person and contrast that with somebody who has been in the company for a long time," I continued. This new person, fairly new, he's trying to get himself settled and everything," I observed. "It was nice for him, it was nice for us to talk," I added. And then I was able to help him on a couple of things that he was trying to figure out on his own. I have had experience with people who have been in my company for a really long time, and then working with them was quite different than working with someone who's completely new and collaborating with that person on that project," I reflected. "So it was refreshing for me to look at how things can be pretty challenging for somebody who has joined something for the first time and taking up a new project," I concluded. "So it was pretty interesting," I smiled.

My Wife and I just arrived in Portland, Oregon. It is our first time to the city. The airport was older, but still OK, we did not spend much time there. We took a lyft to our hotel, and the driver informed us about a protest that was scheduled for that day. We were unaware of that protest. The driver told us that the proud boys, anti-fa, and the pride rally were all meeting to protest one another. 

The protests started peaceful, until the protesters began to interact. At the time, the proud boy group was mostly tame, which is out of character for the group. Surprisingly, anti-fa began attacking the pride rally. I was not expecting this, i thought both groups were aligned on the same side of the political spectrum. Anti-fa attacked pride members with "concrete milkshakes" which were milkshakes make with quick dry concrete. 

This attack happened a block from our hotel. A few hours into the "protest" homeland security dressed in full tactical gear were dispatched and took control of the square where the protests were happening. This was a shock to my wife and I. We were not expecting this when we arrived to Portland! Turns out, this is fairly common in Portland. 

The hotel only told us to avoid the protests, and they did not seem surprised by the officers in tactical gear. One of the most odd experiences we had was the next morning. We ate breakfast at a food truck that was parked in the square where the protests happened. We ate breakfast in a peaceful square on a beautiful morning, like nothing had happened just a few hours before. 

It was truly an interesting start to our trip and something i will not soon forget.

After a long time, I opened up my Xbox and downloaded the latest game that they had, always feeling that console gaming is pretty cool stuff to do as I used to play a lot of games. But lately, when I moved to the US to complete my Masters and also get into a job, I haven't been playing a lot of console games, primarily because I felt that I've grown out of playing games, especially the UI and the complexities in each game. "How do we go about playing them?" I wondered. "Oh my God, this is so complicated to understand. How do I just go ahead and play a game or race a car or whatever?"

So yesterday, on a holiday or Sunday, I went ahead, opened my Xbox, downloaded the latest game, and powered through the UI, which is a little complicated, but I powered through to play a couple of games and I got really engaged. I felt very good yesterday after doing all that task and just playing the game after a long time, playing for about 5 hours.

Playing made me realize how my parents felt or how somebody feels when they are not in touch with a particular aspect of technology.

I'm not sure it's captivating, but I will tell you what I've been thinking about because I listen to a podcast called Hidden Brain, and it's wonderful. The topic of the last piece that I listened to was happiness and what is happiness and who is happy. Does money make you happy? Does fame make you happy? Does beauty make you happy? The answer, according to this person, is none of the above. One of the things is to shift from complaining to doing exactly the opposite of complaining. I was unsure what he was going to say was the opposite of complaining, but he said savoring. And I thought, yes, that's the perfect word. How do you savor? And why do you savor? You savor something that made you happy. The best way to extend that happiness, I think, is to remember it. He has three ways to savor, and all those ways support memory of the event. His idea is to anticipate it. So let's say we're going to the beach. Oh, what will it be like? I wonder if the water will be cold and the sand will be white? Or will it be pink? Will we find shells? Can we build a castle? Step two is to go and experience the beach and say, "Hey. This water is way colder than we thought, but it's still refreshing and the sand is way browner than we thought. But, boy, it really hangs together when you try to build a castle." And you bring good food. Maybe you didn't expect you met somebody fun and so on. The third step is to remember that and go over it with other people. So that's a real good, concrete way to approach what is happiness. That's a God-given right in this country. We say the pursuit of happiness. It's not an easy thing to do. Like listening and hearing, you can hear people talk. But listening is the active endeavor of trying to make sense of what they say. Pursuing happiness is key. Of course, happiness- in order to feel true happiness, it is said, although I'm not a fan of pain or sadness, it is part of life. You need to deal with those things as bumps in the road or turns on the journey. Happiness is a good thing to think about and would be helpful to talk to kids about so that their expectations aren't that from here on in, everything is going to be perfect. Life is a series of problems. In school, we teach you how to solve problems. We're teaching you how to jump in there and make your life better and hopefully other people. That's my Sunday morning thought.

Yeah, so like I've said before, I've been kind of on a job search for the last year. Last week, I had a brilliant idea to reach out to somebody I had interviewed maybe a year and a half ago, because I knew the background he was coming from was a company I wanted to work at. We had ended up chatting when I gave him a tour of my current company, and we hit it off. Since then, we've reached out to each other a couple of times to chat and help each other. I asked him for help the other day to see if he had any connections at the place I was looking for. He immediately responded and connected me to the hiring manager at the company, who agreed to set up a meeting for the next week. It was amazing. What freaked me out, though, was that a few minutes after that conversation, I got a message from my boss asking if I knew this guy. My boss shared a message from the guy saying he wasn't treated well during the interview process at my current place of work. My stomach dropped. Did this guy turn me in? We're looking for a new job. It turned out he didn't do that, and he would never do that. But it was kind of scary for a second.

A few months ago I was at Petco. I saw a woman trying to wrangle a cat inside one of the cat cages while she was cleaning it, so I stopped to offer to help. I held the cat while she was cleaning the cage and he started purring, rubbing his head on my chin, and practically went to sleep in my arms. I got to talking about the cat with the woman, learning a bit of his tumultuous history. There was no way this cat would have all the behavioral problems that the sheet said he did. I chatted for almost an hour and, by the end, I had all but adopted the cat. 

I took him home with me that day, borrowing a carrier from the rescue group to transport him. Although the first few weeks were rough, he integrated well with my other cats. The other young cat hid from him for quite some time, spending almost entire days under the couch and staring at me with eyes that said "Who this guy in my space?" Eventually she snuck out to sniff him before darting away and, one day, I woke up to find them both on the bed. Opposite corners, to be sure, but together on the bed! 

It was a great relief to see everyone be happy. I named him Kismet for the twist of fate that brought him to me. He's been an amazing cat and even a surrogate dad for some kittens I agreed to foster. He's very fond of kittens, letting them crawl all over him and cleaning their ears at every opportunity. 

I'm really glad I met Kismet and I'm even gladder that he'll be a part of my life going forward.

Kind of think of what would be a good story, got a couple in my head, maybe at work today. I don't know, I've been feeling like I just have been given enough to do lately, which is probably one of the reasons I'm looking for another job. They pay me very well, and I don't have to work all that much, so I don't really know why I'm complaining. But, I feel like I need more to do just to feel satisfied. Just today, I had more to do than usual lately. Sometimes it's a lot of stuff today, sometimes it's not that much. More lately it's been not that much. But today, what did I do today? Had like a meeting early in the morning, kind of throughout the day. I was working on a piece of software that I'm trying to build, just kind of in the background, which is like a kiosk browser - it's kind of hard to explain. Also was working on a project in Singapore that we had to leave before finishing installing it. I was working with one of the junior credit technologists on the team since they were the one who put it together, and I'm just kind of the oversight on it, but I need to make sure it all works. So we were debugging it together a couple of times throughout the day.

Yeah, when my wife and I went out on a date tonight, we went shopping and found a toy store, which was fun. I think I've shared before we're going to have a baby soon. And she was at a toy store. And she was like, you know what? Why don't you get her like a stuffed animal? And I was like, okay, that's a good idea. So we found one, I found one. She said it would be good for me to pick it out, so I found a dark brown stuffed bear that was really cute, seemed good quality and very soft. Then my wife had the good idea to get a second identical one, just in case, you know, whatever gets lost or damaged, or even, I don't know, 20 years from now, we want to pull it out and be like, "hey, look how this thing has aged over time compared to the original one." So we got the lady at the front desk to go look for the second bear because they didn't have two of them out at once, and luckily they had one and we ended up buying both. So that should be really nice when one of them becomes.

Hello, hi. Jibo, thinking about wildlife. This is a quick story about the time I was a boy, about eight or nine years old, and I took a family trip to Florida, where they have lots of different wildlife, including lizards. They interested me a great deal, being from New England, where I wasn't used to seeing lizards crawling around. My father and I set up a jar to catch a lizard, which we left out overnight. We were successful and caught a lizard that I was excited to bring home as a pet. However, the family member we were staying with released it when they saw it in the jar. As a young man, I was sad and upset that the lizard I caught was back in the wild. I felt hurt and a little mad. As I got older, I understood that the older relative had done a very kind thing by letting the lizard go. They never explained to me at the time, but I realized they had done a kind thing. The lizard didn't want to be my pet, and it taught me a lesson about respecting animals in their natural habitat. They're not necessarily there for our pleasure by any means.

A memorable moment was recently when I hosted a birthday party for my boyfriend. We rented out a hall and threw a party there. We recently moved to a different city so we have not seen our friends in a while. On his birthday we invited everybody down and had a good turn out. The theme of the party was more of a Hawaiian theme which everyone seemed to enjoy. There were lots of foods, drinks, music and games. 

Seeing everybody get together to celebrate this moment was special. There were also some unexpected gifts that he received. Our kids were also at this party and they put together a dance for their dads birthday. Our kids are young which makes this even cuter. To see his reaction to the dance was memorable. The smile on faces was such a positive feeling. 

Later on that night we ended up taken everybody back to our house. The hall was only rented out for a few hours and it went better than expected so we continued it at home. Some people spent the night since they could not drive back home. 

Waking up that next morning to a house full of people and laughs about the night before was also very memorable.

The most recent and striking memory I have was when I was in the hospital to receive cycle 2 of chemotherapy for my recurrence of Hodgkin's lymphoma. Initially I was supposed to be in the hospital for only 3 days. This stint in the hospital ended up being for 6 days. 

The first day I arrived there to stay overnight, the chemo was not ready to be delivered so I had to stay there for the night for really no reason, away from my wife and daughter. The next day I had to get a CT scan that shouldn't have happened and they had initially thought that they found more cancer in my lungs. We now know that this diagnosis is not correct but it added to the trauma of this visit. Several doctors visited us and said that they wanted to potentially open my chest and take a biopsy of my lungs! 

Once my oncologist put the squash on this, they began chemotherapy. As soon as they got me hooked up to the chemo and the pump started moving it into my body, I had a systematic reaction. My throat closed up, my face swelled and went numb and turned purple, and I couldn't breath. They immediately stopped the treatment. 

Under this terrible stress I no longer wanted to take the treatment. The nurses convinced me otherwise and that I had to take the treatment to fight my cancer so I can still be here for my wife and daughter. So the next morning we tried again with a higher dilution rate and I didn't have a reaction. 

This was a very emotional moment for me because this chemo was going to keep me alive and kill my cancer. Unfortunately it didn't fully do its job though. I am still fighting cancer because it became resistant to prior treatment methods. We are currently trying MAB treatments to see if we can kill it that way and move onto stem cell transplant. 

I pray this works. I am 37 and have a wife and daughter that depend on me. I want to be here for them.

I was visiting my girlfriend's family and we were having a good time at her mom's boyfriend's house where we were all playing Super Smash Brothers Ultimate and enjoying some good food. However, while I was there and we were all relaxing I received a call from my mother who asked if I had spoken to one of my best friends. I replied and told her that I had been texting him but he hadn't replied for a while. She told me that she didn't know if it was true but that something had happened to his mother. I asked her what had happened and my mom told me that his mom had passed away. 

This was a weird situation as I had known his mother for almost my whole adult life so it didn't really feel as if it was possible for it to happen. I denied it immediately assuming it was a rumor since we all didn't know for sure. 

After about half an hour to an hour, my dad called me (he works with my best friend's mom) and told me that it was, in fact, true. My best friend's mom had passed away. There were no words to describe the feeling I felt. I didn't know what to say or how to act towards my best friend. This was a situation that was completely foreign to me. I had lost other people in my life but not anyone as close as a mother. 

It was a tough time but we all got through it and moved forward.

So, we recently went on a vacation to Utah, but we have other vacations coming up. We're going to go to London and Paris on one trip, and then the next trip, we're going to go to Alaska. I've been to Paris one time, and we just spent one day there, but we did so much stuff. We were on our way to West Africa in the Peace Corps. We went up in the Eiffel Tower, went to the Louvre, walked along the Seine, and went into Notre Dame. It was really impressive before it burned down. We saw the Arc de Triomphe. It was a really busy day. We've also been to Alaska before. We took an elder hostel trip in Glacier Bay, and it was just wonderful. We spent the entire week in Glacier Bay at an end that had delicious food. We went to the homes of the people who were our leaders. We got to see what it's like for people to live so far away from everything. We got to see how they store food for the winter and learned if they're more afraid of Moose, and that if you kill a Moose, it's hard to get all the meat in. You have to get friends or make long pack trips. But I'm hoping this next trip will also be fun. This time we will be going to Denali National Park and also the Kenai Peninsula.

I have so many memories but the one which stands out most in my mind, heart and soul is the memory of my daughter getting her driver license. I know to many this may seem like just another day but to me it was bittersweet. 

We left for DMV on a beautiful sunny day. She was going to have to take the road test. She was talking a lot during the car ride there and during the long wait. I know the talking was just her being nervous about the test. She was nervous about driving with a stranger in the car. 

I was unsettled for other reasons. To me this was a milestone in our time together. She was getting a new kind of freedom. A whole new world was opening up for her. She had more freedom and even though this is the natural course for a young girl I couldn't help but dread the day a little. She has grown independent. She would not need me for that much longer. 

I know I did a great job with her and am very proud of her for passing that test with flying colors, It is just slowly moving closer to the time when she will be leaving to live her own life.

Yeah. So, when I was really young, I met this guy in school who was an avid reader, as was I, because my grandfather had a bookstore in a small mountain town in North India. I read a lot, but did not know a lot of people who read as much as I did. And upon meeting The Sky, it turned out that he enjoyed reading Harry Potter as much as I did, which was all the rage back then. We shared a love for reading and a certain set of series. Within a year, he had to leave and move to a different part of the country. Strangely, I never stopped feeling fondness towards him, even after nearly 20 years. There was an opportunity when I came across his profile online, and I reached out to him, saying I would be in India shortly. He seemed excited to see me too. The strangest thing was seeing him after about 18 years. It felt like nothing had changed between us. We connected like fast, old friends, picking up the conversation as though we had never been apart. Sometimes, you meet people you've spent years with just after a short gap, and you've grown apart in strange ways. Other times, you meet someone for a short while, a long time ago, and it's as though they've been on the journey with you. I think that's quite interesting; the connection you can have with certain people.

When I was maybe five or six years of age, we went to visit my cousins Linda and Clyde, who lived with their parents, my Uncle Eldred and Aunt Ruby, on a little farm not far from 5 and 1 Texas. Clyde, about eight or ten years older than me, would often take Linda and me on adventures as he was about to finish high school. On this particular day, we climbed up to the top of the Windmill tower and then went to a tree in the little forest near their house where we climbed up carefully to look at bird's nests with eggs. There were many trees in what we called a shelter belt, a strip of forest between farm plots, where different creatures lived. After looking at all the birds, we went back to my cousin's house to look them up in a big book. We then learned about the different kinds of birds. Clyde had two or three favorite birds, his absolute favorite being what we called the chicken hawk, a term for a bird big enough to carry off a chicken. We also had Sparrow Hawks, commonly called kestrels. We had great fun looking at the different kinds of birds, nests, and eggs, being careful not to disturb the parent birds. In another summer, Clyde had raised a baby redtail hawk after stealing an egg from a chicken hawk. he fed the hawk carefully as it grew to adulthood, coming around to where Clyde was and eating from a little tray from a distance. It was wonderful to watch the hawk eat the offerings.

I must have been about ten years of age when my family - my father, my mother, my sister, and I - went to stay at a tiny little town called Five and one Texas, close to my uncle and auntie's farm near Berlin, Texas. They didn't have enough room in the farmhouse for us, so we stayed in the town a few miles away. It was a tiny town with just a cotton gin, a store, a gas station, and a few houses. The house we stayed in was one of the earliest built in Will, Barter County, Texas, full of interesting stuff. The manager of the gym owned it and offered to rent it to us for $50 a month but we had to clean it up. We agreed, moved out old radios and trunks full of stuff into a shed-like room. Among the items was a Confederate army uniform from the 1860s with a belt and buckle that said "CSA." We fixed up the house but upon returning one day, we found it in flames. The owner had burned everything. We salvaged the ashes into a garden and stayed in the house for six weeks, working the fields for watermelons and cotton. It was a very interesting summer in Five and one Texas.

When I was maybe six or seven years old, we lived in Gruber, Texas. Our neighbors, Mr. and Mrs. Meeks, had a daughter named Jane who babysat for us. The Meeks family owned a movie theater. On Saturday mornings, I helped clean up the theater with Mr. Meeks and Jane. It was a messy job - we picked up popcorn boxes, soda cups, and swept the floor. In exchange for my help, I got to watch a movie and have popcorn and a cold drink. I loved going to the theater, even though I couldn't go into the projection room. Mr. Meeks let me stand at the door and watch him work. I enjoyed seeing all the mechanics behind showing a movie on the screen from high up in the back. They showed cereals, cartoons, and the main movie on Saturday mornings starting at 10:00. My friends were proud and maybe a bit jealous that I got to be there before the movie opened. It was an exciting part of town where families dropped off their kids for the movie before going about their day. Helping clean up the Moving Picture Theater was a wonderful little job that I had.

Now, I don't know if you got the story about picking the cotton, but here's another one: about picking cotton when I was avoiding. At the end of the year after the cotton was harvested, the field would have to be plowed under, and there might be some remnants of cotton still left. The cotton plants were all dried out, but there were still some fibers left on the plants. So the farmer I worked for, Mr. and Mrs. Hale, would come out on a Saturday morning and get me. I would go back to their farm, and they would go quickly through the field, picking the low amount of cotton that was left after most of the leaves were gone and most of the plants were all dried up. While they were running through the fields quickly picking the remains of the cotton, I would be putting gasoline in their old tractor. They had a wonderful big farm oil tractor that I liked and enjoyed working with that machine. I would check the oil and I would fill it up with gasoline. I would take some from a standing tank and put it into a small can. Then we'd get over to the tractor and put it into the tank of the tractor. I would check the spark plugs and make sure everything was in good shape. Then I would start it up and I would plow under the old cotton peel, which was a very interesting chore. I would make a spiral starting at the outside of the field. And we used what was called a disc herald, a kind of plow that will turn the soil over and simply cut up all the plants and get the soil ready for it to be lying and fallow for a few months before the next planting season. They would put all the vegetative matter back into the soil so that it could compost and make the soil richer. It was not a precise job. I could make a spiral. I did not have to keep a careful rule like you do if you're planting or cultivating or harvesting. The plowing under is very free-form and it was a great fun to make a big spiral around the outside of the field, making it smaller and smaller with every circle of the field. There would be a lot of animals, like the cottontail rabbits, occasionally a jackrabbit, sometimes a quail, and occasionally rattlesnakes that you would see after you'd chopped up and broken the soil of one place. Those animals would go to the middle of the field. As the middle of the field got smaller and smaller, where there was vegetation, then the animals would take off and go to cover outside of the field. So it was very interesting and exciting to see all those different creatures leaving the field and going to what we call a berm, which is a place outside the field that was full of vegetation, a good place for the animals to hide.

My daughter decided to play fast pitch softball and just finished their tournament in 2nd place. During her last game a month ago, she hit a double and even caught a few balls in the outfield. I was so proud of her and the achievements she has made over the past few months playing softball. 

The double was a huge deal for her. She knew that she hit the sweet spot on the bat because she could hear the familiar sound. She was at a 3-2 count so anything could have happened. She could have let her nerves wear her down and just strike out. 

However, she was patient and focused. She was able to harness her potential and made a big play for her team. She immediately ran to first base and then second with seconds to spare. A runner was able to make it home and score. 

We were ahead with two out and my daughter on second. She was eventually batted in and scored a run to place the team two points ahead. They barely won the game but they also learned a very important lesson. 

Sometimes you have to face down your fear to make great things happen.

When I was about twelve years old, my family lived in Texas most of the year, but in New Mexico for the summers. We built cabins, little houses, and sold them for profit, getting to know people around us in Ruidoso. We went to a little church where the minister had a daughter, Eileen, who was my age. Eileen and I were friends with the kids at the church, and we played mini-golf on Monday nights at a course owned by one of the fellows there. On Wednesday nights, there was choir practice, and Sunday there were church services. One day, Eileen asked me out on a date, my very first date ever.

We met at the roller skating rink in Ruidoso on a crowded Saturday afternoon, and I paid for her entrance. She showed me how to order shoes and tie them up, giving me a roller skating lesson before we spent an hour and a half skating together. Her parents came to pick her up for a family dinner, so I said my goodbyes and thanked her for a great time before heading home. I excitedly shared my first date experience with my family, who congratulated me on a good time roller skating with Eileen.

To call this story "The Snow Day," I grew up in a very small town called Christoval, in the middle of a bunch of ranches and farms where only a couple of hundred people lived. One Saturday night after a basketball tournament, my friend Manuel was going to stay at my house and then go to church with my family. My father, who was the superintendent of schools, decided there would be no school on Monday after it started snowing early that morning. Manuel ended up staying with us the whole day and the following Monday. The snow began melting off around 10:00 in the morning, but school was still canceled. So, Manuel and I drove 20 miles to San Angelo on Monday afternoon to watch a James Bond movie. At the end of the movie, we went to an A&W Root Beer place for hamburgers, French fries, and root beer. Unfortunately, my old car wouldn't start after our meal, but luckily Manuel's cousins were at the restaurant and helped us push-start the car. We then made it back home over the snowy roads to Nicobacher where Manuel lived, while I went back to my home in Christoval. Overall, it was a beautiful and snowy day off from school, making it one of my favorite snow days ever.

The video I'm about to describe was in early June of 1964 when my family moved to a new town. I was 16 and sad because I left a lot of friends behind in the old town where I had lived for 8 years. My parents found better jobs in the new town, so we moved. Around 6:00 a.m. on my first night in our new house, I heard knocking and found two guys my age named Philip and Bobby at the door. They asked if I was Fred and invited me fishing. Surprised, I was told to also wear work clothes because they got me a job. My dad greeted them, and we had coffee and biscuits. We then drove to the river to check the trotline they set up to catch catfish. After catching some fish, we went to haul hay in the countryside for about 6 hours. Back in town, we had watermelon for lunch. I made friends with boys and girls living there, including Manuel and Oscar. We had a swim in the river and went our separate ways. I went home for a nap, and my dad asked how my first day was. I said it was wonderful, and I was glad we moved there.

All right, so today, I wanted to talk about the moment when I faced an unexpected setback in my career development and how it changed my perspective of growth. I think more than about two and a half years ago, I was working one full-time position at a startup and handling another part-time job at another startup. I was also doing one pro bono job at a nonprofit organization and a freelance gig for another nonprofit organization. I was handling like four jobs at the same time, which was crazy if I think about it. But I don't know why that happened, but I just happened to have a lot of tasks, and I didn't decline any of the work because I was hungry for career growth and wanted to accept challenges to grow my skills much faster.

Also, this was possible because one of my full-time positions at the startup was back in South Korea, so I was working full-time during the daytime and part-time during the day for the other startup in Santa Clara, California. I was doing freelance and pro bono work during the weekend. So this was possible time-wise, but this definitely wasn't good for my mental health. I was going through a lot of pressure and stress. I wasn't as skilled using the software and didn't have a lot of experience, so I wasn't as confident as I am now. I was going through a lot of mental stress and actually had to learn some stuff while I was doing the work at the same time. I had an issue with prioritizing what's important and what's not, and some work had to be pushed back. It was definitely a very hard time. I wasn't doing well back at home because I was very stressed at work, easily losing my temper with my partner. I didn't have much time to relax. So not a lot, but I slept like a decent amount, but I still didn't feel like I was energetic or invigorated because of the stress, I guess. That was also very anxious. So a lot of things were happening.

But I did that because if I had some leisure time, I didn't know what to do with my leisure time and felt like I was wasting my time. I wanted to catch up with my career because I entered this path pretty late compared to many other people. So I wanted to catch up quickly with my skills and with my career. So I didn't want to waste my time. So I felt like keeping myself busy would help me to be more progress, help me to grow. I just wanted to keep myself busy with a lot of tasks. But obviously, it didn't work well because it was too much work and too much pressure. And I wasn't ready for it, I guess. All those challenges, so one of my coworkers at my full-time position felt with my coworker, and he quit because of that. I was laid off from my part-time position because I couldn't deliver what I promised. One of my full-time positions at another startup in Korea also didn't go well. The company was facing south, and it was going south. So I landed on another company in South Korea by recommendation from a coworker. So all my hard work, these challenges, didn't pay off as much as I wished. I went through very I went through a little depression because of all that because I didn't end up achieving what I said at the beginning. I thought I would be very successful at handling everything, but it didn't. So I was very disappointed in myself. And I even felt guilty and bad about myself because of all the situations like I was laid off, I fought with my coworker, and he quit. So I felt guilty, and I thought I was doing something wrong. I just reflected on myself a lot. And it wasn't good. 

Anyway, so I have to think back and reassess what I was doing and why all this was happening. And since I quit after a couple of months, I told the nonprofit that I would stop doing the pro bono work, and I kind of clear all the other tasks and just focus on the full-time position. So I had some time to think about my past work and experiences that I had. And instead of keeping myself busy with all those challenges, I decided to invest in new hobbies. I just took some online classes for drawing and registered for personal training to exercise. So I filled those void with some other build of outer field of life. I guess I filled it with my hobbies. And all that instead of keeping myself busy with the career-related work. I think it actually helped me to recover from the bad experience. It helped me to, I think, develop other interests in life other than the career. Really helped me because it paid back. For example, I started to connect my other interests and use that interest to inspire myself and push myself in my career. I started to realize that sometimes, being productive, trying to be productive, I need to have a more rich experience and grow internally other than just keeping myself busy and doing external work. I hope it makes sense.

Okay, so today, I want to talk about how my perspective about my background or my family lineage has changed. My father is pretty conservative, and he emphasized a lot about our family background from a prestigious family with high-ranking scholars and queens. He always emphasized that we are a prestigious family and should be successful in society. As a child, I felt proud, but as I grew up, it seemed like such a long time ago, back in the Jeonju or Goryeo Dynasty. I always thought my father must not be very happy about his accomplishments in life, which is why he focused on finding glory from the past. I was more focused on my individuality rather than my family background. Nowadays, people in the democratic world care about their ancestors, and as I immigrated to the United States, I realized the importance of collective power and being part of a community. Being part of the MIT community helped me network and get a job, showing how the group you belong to can be meaningful. In the US, I thought more about my identity as a Korean American and my ancestral lineage. Although I had a negative perspective towards South Korea before, I now think more about it and want to make a positive impact like my ancestors did. I believe that finding a group and connecting with a larger community can bring positive changes to society. I am proud of my ancestors and want to make a positive impact as a South Korean immigrant. I now think about a bigger picture than myself and hope to make my future children proud.

All right, so today I want to share a story about my marriage. I got married in 2016 when I was around 20. I didn't think I would marry my husband a year before I got married to him. Everything evolved fast with environmental issues involved, leading to my decision to marry him. I've been married to my husband since 2015, now 2020, right? Seven years. I reflect on my marriage to discuss the pros and cons, as I've noticed some negative perceptions towards marriage in South Korea. I had a conventional perspective before I got married due to media influence and family discussions. I was scared of not finding a partner as I got older. The fear of missing my prime time and not being able to sell myself also influenced my decision to get married. I believed my husband was trustworthy and sincere, which was crucial for a successful marriage. Over the years, I saw some pros of marriage, like saving money and focusing on other life tasks once the marriage task was completed. Building a family matured me, despite the challenges and arguments we faced. We negotiated and compromised our differences, leading to a more mature relationship. Having my husband's emotional support made me feel more stable and less lonely. However, there were cons, such as having to work more to take care of each other emotionally and compromising on interests. Less freedom and excitement were also noted as cons. It's important to marry someone with similar values to shape life decisions together. Getting to know your partner well before marriage is crucial as their values and judgments can influence your life significantly.

Okay, so I want to talk about something I noticed recently. I feel different when interacting with certain groups. I'm more comfortable with some people than others. The issue is that it's based on race. I wanted to figure out why and also because I felt bad. Honestly, I feel more comfortable speaking to African Americans. When I speak to white Americans, I feel intimidated, like I'm putting my guard up. I'm more careful about what I say, going through censorship. It's weird, and I want to feel more like myself regardless of who I'm interacting with. Most biases come from past experiences. I reflected on my past and saw I had better experiences with African Americans. When I was 14, I studied abroad in Canada. I was the only person of color and had a hard time mingling due to cultural barriers. Nobody would sit next to me, which hurt. I felt transparent and gave up trying to make friends. This experience has had a lasting impact on me. I avoided similar situations. Memories were affecting me without my awareness. I felt fear when interacting with similar people. I had a positive experience at an African American university when I was 20. I was more mature and had an easier time making friends. It was easy to mingle as a group. Reflecting on past experiences has helped me realize my biases. Now, I strive to be more open-minded and aware of my feelings towards different groups.

Okay. So I moved to the US in 2016, but for the past couple of years, I only worked for Korean companies or Korean-owned companies due to some circumstances. I was really curious to know about the corporate cultures in the US and how the workplace culture is like in the US. Since I started to work for a US company starting from last week, I'm really excited and a little bit overwhelmed about this new experience, but mostly I'm excited. Starting from the onboarding or background check and everything was very stressful even before I start working for the company. I only worked for companies in a smaller size so I haven't really been through this rigorous background check. I was actually very surprised at how the companies were conducting background checks very rigorously. It was a bit surprising, but I was very glad that I didn't write any false experience or anything misleading in my resume. Everything that I wrote on the resume was I was able to prove it. So I was really glad for myself. I learned that I really need to be honest in every situation because I never know what's coming in the future. So that was like one of the insights that I gained during this onboarding experience. I've learned that US corporate culture is much more parallel and they encourage collaborations, open discussion, very much so. It seems like a relationship with the peers is really important. I'm a little bit of an introvert so I'm not always very proactively approach people, but I feel like I have to because I'm the new person here, so I have to be more proactive and approach other team members and introduce myself, be more friendly to make new connections. So that's another thing that I've learned from this experience. I learned that the team really encourages me to get involved as much as I can in other projects and be very proactive and take initiative, speak up during the meetings. So I guess it's very different from Korean culture in Korean corporate culture. If you are being overly engaging and if you take initiative, even if you're a newcomer, then it's a little bit it means it's a little bit people could give you. It could leave a bad impression because it makes you look like you are overly confident or overly rude. It could come across as a rude person, but I learned it's necessary and I need to look confident and say confidently when I communicate with my coworkers. Because if I act or say things that make me look humble, then it could easily come across as a lack of confidence in the US. I'm trying to be more cautious thinking about that. So I'm trying to calibrate myself to the US corporate culture. These are the three things that I've learned so far, and I'm trying to adapt to the new environment.
