I feel good about this new team and the new company and my position as well. I'm really glad that I had this opportunity. I'm really happy about it. I'm looking forward to sharing more insight as I work in this company.

So, I'm a design researcher, a product researcher, a UX researcher, whatever you want to call it. Design researcher everywhere I go, I introduce kind of new things and new approaches to my jobs and my coworkers, and fortunately, I keep getting a lot of positive feedback, like, "Oh, I'm so glad to work with you. Oh, this is so interesting." I find it to be less because I'm more skilled or more knowledgeable than anyone else. I just know what's right to do for the research objective. Maybe in that way, I just propose more, like, maybe I'm just more ambitious. But it's scary and it's harder, and maybe that's why people don't do it, but I feel a responsibility to do it. I find that inspires people. It's really difficult for me, a constant path of learning. I always have to learn something new, kind of a burden, and I understand why people wouldn't really want to do that. It's tiring. But I hope it will be rewarding, and it seems like the right thing to do. It seems like the right answer, and I think it'll get me where I want to be as a researcher in my career, making the amount of money that I want to make, with the titles that I want to have, at the companies that I want to work for. I'm glad I have some people on my team that support me, but it's scary and it's hard, and I always have to learn, and I never have enough resources.

I'm going to tell you about a really difficult time in my life, both stressful and emotionally challenging. It's the story of my miscarriage and trying to switch career paths. Not this past June, but a year from last June, I had been submitting my application for a new career shift into product design. During that process, I found out I had become pregnant accidentally. I was emotionally struggling with the idea of applying for a job and having a child unexpectedly at 40 with all the costs. Not to say having a child is all burdens, but there's a big financial situation to stress about. I reached out to my company contact and was excited to hear it wouldn't deter them from a potential job fitting. I had come around to the idea of having a child and we all got really excited. My son was too. Then, in the same week on a Tuesday, I went to the doctor and there was no heartbeat. That was really surprising and emotionally stressful. I was about twelve weeks along and had to figure out what to do. I decided to have surgery. On Wednesday, I had to figure out my miscarriage and prep for my final job interview the next day. Alongside that was the frustrating financial cost of surgery with little healthcare support. Wednesday was busier with hospital talks and scheduling my appointment while also preparing for the whiteboarding challenge in the job interview. The job interview on Thursday went great, but I didn't know if I got the job. Friday morning at 05:00 A.M., I had the surgery which was emotionally challenging. Later that day, I found out I got the job. Throughout it all, I was trying not to feel too much because it would break me down. Saturday morning, I finally let it all out and felt both relieved and supported by my partner. It was a week full of unexpected challenges, but it showed me I can handle a lot and make my way through it.

I had never had a pet but I always wanted to. However my mom would always say no because there was nobody home to take care of a pet. I had hamsters, fish and other small pets, but I wanted a real pet that I could pet and feed. I think it had to be a dog because I don't like cats. 

Well, I had never thought about a rabbit. It was in a magic show that we had where this cutie pie was. I loved her when I first saw it. I think rabbits are so cute but I had never been close to one. 

Well, I participated to be able to get her as mine. I didn't think of what my parents could say. but soon she was given to me and I could take her home. It was funny that my mom didn't like her at first, but a few days later she was just in love with this fluffy thing. 

I have read a lot about rabbits to be able to take care of her. I love her. She is growing fast and likes to be pet, which I love because I thought rabbits always wanted to be alone. No, she loves to be whenever there are people and likes to lick and be pet, and gets excited when we come home just like a dog.

So today, I'm going to talk about a revelation I had over the weekend after talking with my partner. I realized that I've been bullied in my office, which is a really new territory for me because I'm older. I have about 20 years of experience, and I've never come across this. I woke up Sunday morning, just woke up really early. My brain started churning, and I started to cry and just feeling miserable because I'm just spinning in my head about why this one coworker, this product manager, is just so outwardly horrendous. For a while there, it's been kind of a series of patterns over the last nine months. It was difficult because this was a new career path for me. Initially, I was thinking, oh, well, I have a lot of gaps to fill, I don't know. Push a project forward with feeling like I was being incompetent. There were times when she completely lashed out at me and was like, "This is not design!" and just really erratic behavior. I try to bring up on the group channel like, "Hey, I need some review on this," and she'll just pick out the most random things to be like, "Well, this is not best us practice. I'm wondering why you did this," and send me a Nielsen Norman article across the chat. If I try to ask questions about the progress of a product in one of our features and development, she'll just give me a blank answer and then ask our program manager to tell the group what the purpose of this feature is. It's been really, kind of jarring her behavior. At first I just thought, okay, she's an aggressive personality. Then I tried to find patterns with other people, and it wasn't there. And so I definitely went inward until I actually just took a step back and was doing some online research about workplace bullying. It is what she is doing, it's outward yelling at fellow coworkers in meetings, which is obvious. But then it's other things, like overly micromanaging every little detail or pointing out constant ridicule or actually talking in platitudes that are really hard to defend against. It's withholding information. It's not bringing team members in as part of when decision making is happening. It's been a complete, repeated pattern. It actually feels really good because I've been able to identify what the behavior is and to realize honestly that I'm doing a great job. It's not on me. I've had an office bully. It sounds really funny also to say. It's hard to bring up because it's not an easy pattern to identify because it's not across the board in every situation with other coworkers, I mean. It's a really targeted micro like aggression. To me, it sounds silly to bring up because it's almost like schoolyard playground behavior. I really try not to play a victim, very assertive. So I just kind of was shrugging it off as, "Alright, it's just a different personality to work with," but it's actually a behavior in the workplace and it feels really good to have identified it so I can just release and put it for what it is.

Over here, the story I'm going to share today is about my trip home and rediscovering some new but very old clothing. Growing up, I feel like I never really had a sense of style because my mom would just buy all my clothes for me; she knew my sizes, she knew how to look for clothing on sale - she's really good at that. So, I never really had to worry about, like, "Oh, what clothes do I wear?" because there was just a bunch of clothing to pick from. But she also knew my style, which was, like, not my taste, but what I didn't like - super bold, bright colors, scary patterns, and prints - so I would typically just wear very basic, neutral clothing. As of recently, I think I've been a little bit more adventurous and exploratory with my clothing; I've been wearing more color, wearing more styles, not just the shorts and shirt every day, but sometimes a dress. Now I have an interest in shoes, which is exciting - I never really was a shoe person until now because I worked in labs all my life, so I was always wearing, like, sneakers, but now I'm like, "Yeah, it would be nice to kind of have some heels once in a while." So, I went home and, in addition to some shopping, most of the clothing I brought back from my trip was actually old clothes that my mom had bought when she was younger, as well as clothing that my sister doesn't wear anymore. She's younger than me, but we have the same-ish size and body, so I can steal from her closet. It's kind of incredible that my mom has saved clothing for, like, 20 years and now she's passing them to me, and they're still such good quality, so cool and trendy - that's just really enjoyable. I'm glad that I was able to get some clothing from home from my mom physically - it makes me think about the clothing I buy now and whether or not it's even worth passing on to my kids and how long those pieces will last, staying in style. But I have a lot to learn, so I definitely don't know enough about fashion, but I think it's really cool, and I want to learn more.

So this is the story of going perfume shopping with my mom. Originally, we went to the mall not to buy perfume, but to try on dresses for my white coat ceremony coming up. But in the mall, there are a bunch of different stores, and my mom doesn't really go out on her own to shop. She likes having someone shopping with her. My dad is too busy with work, so when I went home, she spent time with me. We decided just to go through some random stores because why not? We were there already, and I noticed one of the brands that I really like now called Boutique. I really wanted to show my mom the perfume that I had gotten over the summer as a gift from someone, but they sold out of it because it was limited edition. Instead, I introduced her to a bunch of other scents, knowing that she really likes jasmine because I also like jasmine. She tried it on, and we left. Then she had to go back. It was like we only walked like ten steps out of the store before she was like, no, I should do this for myself. So we went back in and we got her the perfume. It's really nice. I think my mom is someone who is always afraid to spend money because we don't have a lot of it. So she's really frugal, but we're at a place financially where my family can be nicer and more spendy. I was really happy that she was able to buy a perfume that she really liked. We went home, she unboxed it, sprayed some on, loved the smell. I'm so happy. It makes her happy. She's super deserving of it. And now I have a memory that every time I go home and smell jasmine or smell jasmine in my day-to-day life, I'll think of my mom and the perfume we got together.

Today, I hung up a shelf in my apartment; my dad is quite the handyman at home. If our toilet ever has problems, he fixes it, and if our car ever breaks down, he's the one who fixes it as well. So for most of my life, he's the one who puts hardware together and sets things up. As part of moving into this apartment, we have some furniture that was just laying on the ground. I was like, "Okay, it should be time you just put it up somewhere, like, make our home feel like a home." So for the first time in my life, ever, I use a screwdriver to drill a hole in the wall manually, and then stuck the two like drywall plastic bits in. It was honestly quite a struggle, and I was sweating. Without the help of my roommate, I would have definitely failed. But now it's hanging up there, and we have books on it; it's really cute. I'm just so happy that we did this, and kind of proud too. I knew I was kind of capable, but to actually just have followed through and finished this tiny little project feels really good. So that's my shelf over there, which is why I keep looking over there; that's my story for this session.

Yeah, so like I kind of mentioned already, today was a really stormy day, but I already had made plans with my program little to hang out. It's my first time really hanging out with her outside of campus at her apartment, my first time being in our apartment. So this morning, I woke up and decided to go to Whole Foods. I walked, like 30 minutes in the rain to go to Whole Foods to pick up flowers, really cute bottles, and some groceries. I spent a long time looking for flowers, trying to find ones that would fit her personality. I got her an arrangement with a bunch of different flowers in a really nice glass vase. It was super fun. We hung out, talked a lot, played three games of pool, and made a Chinese dessert called Simulu, which is like tapioca pearls with fruits and coconut milk. It was really yummy. Then I came home while it was still raining. So today, if it wasn't for my little and having so much stuff to do, I think I would have been just as gloomy as the weather. It made me really happy to have done so much today. Yes, that's my story.

Yes, so today for dinner, I went out with the Crabstones in my lab because we were celebrating the return of a rotation student. Usually in our program, there are a lot of PhD programs. Your first year is spent rotating, working in different labs until you find your home lab. We had an MD, PhD student rotate for his second rotation. We were sad when he went for his third and hopeful that he would come back. He officially started today and it was super fun. We cleaned out his bench together. I think our lab is just really nice in the sense that we like to leave the lab once in a while and help each other. We had a little dinner together and tried a lot of different dishes because we did Family Style, which is so much more fun than getting things for yourself to eat. One of the fun things was at the end of the night, while we were leaving, I was brave enough to ask the waitress lady if I could take one of the plant propagations. They have a lot of plants in that restaurant, all of them decorating like little glass bowls. "Can I have one, please?" I said. I think it was really brave of me because I normally would never ask. But I really wanted one of those plants. They are so cute. The lady said, "Yeah, sure." She handed me one and I felt so, like, wow. Brave. Also, like, yeah, it's not too scary to ask. What's the worst that could happen? If she said no, bummer. Okay, yeah, understandable. But I was kind of proud of myself that I was able to ask for a little plant propagation, and hopefully I'll keep it growing and add another plant to my plant family. So yeah, that's my story of today.

Six years ago, a matchmaking site called "Book lovers" (this was before the internet) matched me with a man named Matters from California, who seemed perfect to me - interested in everything and attractive too. He decided to move to Pennsylvania to be with me, as my family owned a week in this house. Very quickly, it became evident that he was responsible but lacked motivation. He would just read books and waste time. To encourage him to do something, I suggested he go back to school and learn computer programming, which was guaranteed to be a very good career at the time. I paid for his tuition so he could learn about programming, showing how old the story is. He would go off to school, and I was proud of him for working hard and learning how to program. One day, a friend of mine who lived at the school he attended told me that my boyfriend really likes to read and would come to the library and leave magazines. When he got back that day, I confronted him about it and told him that I couldn't put up with his lack of ambition in my life. It was the best decision I ever made, and it felt like a huge weight was lifted off my shoulders.

No gbo, this was not recent at all, this was many decades ago while I was still in high school in the early 70s. My friends and I participated in an activity called Pennsylvania Junior Academy of Science, a science fair where high school kids from the area competed for awards. You had to present the results of the research that you did. So at the time, I was very interested in microbiology, well before smartphones that you can use to take micrographs. I had to jury-rig a contraption with an old box camera poised over the eyepiece of my microscope, and a little fishbowl with a light bulb for temperature control. I had a hay infusion to collect some protozoa and used this to conduct experiments about different things that can affect protozoa in their insisted dormant stage. I presented at the local meeting of this. My boyfriend at the time also presented a project which he claimed showed that baby chicks could be conditioned while they were still in their eggs. And to do this, he wrapped wires around some fertilized eggs and attached the wires to a Big Ben alarm clock, one of those really, really loud, old-fashioned alarm clocks. Every day, he would set this alarm off so the bell would ring. So when the chicks finally hatched, he then set off the alarm clock and they, of course, went crazy, running around and cheeping squawking. He claimed that this was because they were conditioned while they were filling the egg to respond to the sound. The obvious, obvious question was, "Well, don't you think that any chicks conditioned or not would go crazy with this huge sound, this very scary alarm?" But when he presented, the judges didn't ask that question, and they in fact awarded him a first prize for this project. I got honorable mention, and it turned out the reason why I only got an honorable mention was that they didn't think that I did this project without any help. So you see, jivo, 50 odd years later, this still bothers me, but I did learn a valuable lesson about the just world fallacy.

Well, I was in graduate school and a member of various fandoms before the Internet. Fandoms consisted of fanzines that you got through the mail. Through these fanzines, I heard about a medieval reenactment organization that did a lot of really great activities. It sounded like something I would love to get involved with. Where I live, this wasn't an option. There were no local groups in this reenactment society. But I went to Penn State for my doctorate, and they had a branch group on campus for this reenactment society. So I met with the person in charge, and he set me up with all the information that I needed.

When I got back home after graduate school was finished, I decided to start my own local group. So I did this totally from scratch. I didn't have anybody that I personally knew who would be interested in this. So I actually submitted a little invitation in the newspaper and set up a meeting at the local library for anyone who would be interested in joining. I was so nervous that day, I was so nervous that people wouldn't show up, that I had a physical reaction. My stomach was in knots. I couldn't endure the tension.

But the day came, and I went to the library. And when I saw about ten people sitting there waiting for me, I felt such relief. And I felt such pride. In the years since, the local group that I started has become recognized. They have had many more members join and have hosted various events. And I am very proud of what I accomplished that day.

Today was a terrible day for me. My co-worker, who we will call the big "W" is usually always mean to me. However, today she was the worst. It was our big Christmas party, and she micromanaged everyone at work today. She started openly complaining about only she was smart, only she did any real work, etc. 

Everyone had told me since I started here how terrible she was and how badly they wanted her to be fired. Despite this, no one would ever do anything about her or talk about her until she left the room. 

Finally I snapped and decided not to sit down and take it like everyone else. While she started insisting she told me to do something I was never told, I told her to her face she never said that. She lost it and started to scream at me, while she did that my boss just ignored it like he usually did. 

I decided I had enough of a boss that wouldn't do anything and handed him my resignation, which was more than he deserved. He tried to convince me it was cowardly to leave, but I told him it was cowardly to not fire her. 

She kept harassing me through the night until that point, then my boss decided to take her to the back room and yell at her for having a coworker finally quit over her. She came back out and stayed quiet for the whole rest of the night. 

I left that job and felt good about leaving, they all already didn't like her but it was made worse once she actually cost them a good employee who at least tried their best which was more than half of the people they hired did.

So, not sure how to start this story, I have a lot of friends, which is a lovely thing, but it means that, depending on the week or the season, I hang out with some people more than others. I have had a relatively new friend called Luisa, who I thought we were on the same page as far as how often we could hang out, and I hadn't seen her for a while. She travels during the summer and the fall as she's an instructor, she's a professor, so as soon as summer comes, she's gone for the entire duration of the summer, which is several months. She goes to Columbia, and then she does the same when it's the holiday time from like Christmas, and we've gotten used to not really contacting each other during the time when she's out of the country, even when she's in the country, we see each other sporadically, which I thought was fine. I enjoy her company, she's very funny, she's got a good sense of humor. I like her husband, they're nice eggs, good eggs. But it turns out that we had a misunderstanding about how often we'd hang out together, and she kind of gave me a severe talking to a while ago about not hanging out with her which I think had the opposite effect of what she hoped, now I just feel guilty when I don't hang out with her, and when I do hang out with her, I feel like I'm doing it out of obligation. All that to say, she is having a baby shower this Saturday, tomorrow, and I have yet to RSVP, I think I'm not going to go, I don't like baby showers at all. We haven't talked to each other, and I think it'd be really awkward to go to a kind of intimate event without having spoken to her first, but I think it will seal the fate of the relationship, I think this will be the last straw. So, I'm going to do it, but it's on my mind as the day approaches.

So, I had the Open House event, and then a good friend of mine from grad school wanted to take a trip to Portland for a few days afterwards. The Open House was on Sunday, and we left on Tuesday for a few days. I just returned last night, which was Friday, Saturday night, and during the vacation, I received a notice from the Austin City Code people that the activity I'd hoped to have in the space, which is the art Studios, goes against city code. Honestly, I had hoped to be able to stand at the radar and host artists in the space without really raising the flags with the city. I think that's the way arts organizations have worked in Austin, in residential areas. Artists just get together and work at each other's homes and no one's the wiser per se. But I think my error is that I put some Flyers in neighbors' mailboxes, just like four up the street, and one kind of across from me, like my nearest neighbors, and someone didn't like the activity and reported me to the city. So, that was a big shocker on vacation because I really don't have that much of a Plan B for this property. I've spent 26 months renovating.

About 2 months ago, one of our employees had a breakdown due to his family leaving. His family left him due to personal issues that they've been having. I was called because his neighbors thought that he had suicidal ideation due to his wife and kids leaving, and was advised that he had weapons in his house. 

At this time, I was very scared and it took me a moment before I realized what I needed to do. This man needs help immediately and that he can't be alone. So, I called the cops and responded to his home and found out that he wasn't suicidal but was just going through a lot. 

I asked him if he needs someone to be with him or if he wants to stay the night over in my place. He replied saying he just wants to be alone and that everyone deals with problems differently. He rest assured that he isn't going to hurt himself and that he is just looking forward to tomorrow. I took possession of his weapons to err on the side of caution and he didn't have any issue with it. 

The next day, he came and spoke to me and said that he has alcohol substance abuse, hence why his family left him. He self referred himself to the clinic. He then had to go into a rehab facility for 4 weeks. He finished the program 1 week early as he did great and actually came up with his own goals. 

His family came back home and they have been doing really well. He continues to attend Alcohol Anonymous meetings and continues to build his network of friends that he can rely on.

A few months ago at the Styx concert, He surprised me and proposed. After 13 years of being together, I actually never thought it would happen. 

The song "Lady" started and he gave his phone to a person we didn't know behind us. I thought that was really strange but it didn't dawn on me that there could be any other reason but that he wanted someone to take our picture together. That annoyed me because I don't like getting my picture taken. 

The next think I new, he was talking in my ear so I could hear him over the loud music and then he got down on one knee. Next he held out a ring he pulled from his pocket. I started crying and said, "yes, definitely yes!". I was in total shock. 

Even though I don't like to have my picture taken, I'm so glad he had someone videotape the proposal. It's really funny to see the shocked look on my face. 

After the proposal, he told me that he first got permission from my girls and my dad as well. I thought that was a very noble gesture and something that he didn't have to do. 

Now we have a wedding to plan. I feel so blessed to marry the love of my life who is also my best friend. I wonder how I ever got so lucky.

Roughly 3 weeks ago me and my girlfriend of a year broke up. It had been coming for a while, but i do not think it was something i was ready to fully accept. About 4 months ago, she got very sick. During this period where she was sick, she was completely bed ridden and i did not get to see her often. 

There was a lot of tension between us because of this. It started with us starting to say hateful stuff towards each other. I would tell her that i hated i never got too see her, and that it felt like i was not even in a relationship. She told me that she's sorry i felt that way, but I needed to get over myself. This of course, hurt me very much. 

We had been friends for years before we even considered dating, and the relationship was starting to fade. I could not bring myself to end it at the time, so we continued. The situation worsened as time went on. We went from remarks, to full on hating each other. She would come over and i would tell her that i did not want to see her. I started having anxiety attacks thinking about what the relationship was coming to. 

When my birthday came around, I sat her down and told her that I was seriously not happy with the relationship, and it needed to end. She agreed and i have not talked to her since. This event has been very hard on me as, because this was someone i wanted to build a life with and within one night, it was all gone.

Today, all week we have been on the warning for a Hurricane here on the North Shore in Massachusetts, and it's always a little worrisome. You have to get your extra groceries in the house and all that. I live about 2 miles from the ocean. So a friend came out this afternoon. We went to the beach to watch the waves. Right before these storms come in, the waves go crazy and it's really clear that a storm is brewing. So the sky was still blue and it was actually quite pretty. But it still means that a storm is brewing, so it's going to happen tomorrow. It's no longer a Hurricane, but they say it's going to be a pretty fierce storm with high winds. So we'll see what it brings tomorrow. It's part of living near the Coast. A lot of things for tomorrow have been canceled, outdoor concerts, art shows, etc. But I think it will be fine. I'm okay as long as we keep the power going because that's always a danger of these storms. That a tree falls on the lines and all that and we do get power outages living so near the coast. It always makes me feel like, yeah, I can prepare for this. It will be good, and the sun will come out again. And it will be interesting to see what tomorrow brings. As long as we keep the power, I should be okay.

Okay, here's my story for today, recently, we had a documentary film festival here in town and I sat through quite a few movies. One of them has been staying on my mind. It was a documentary about four students from Africa, places like Rwanda, Nigeria, countries like that, who got a scholarship to study at MIT. It was quite fascinating to see where these people came from, how they adjusted to life in Cambridge. The weather is different, food is different, social norms are different, the culture is different, and they have to perform at a very high level. It was very interesting to watch these students as they went home. They really wanted to contribute to their country, the things they had learned at MIT, some with good results and others not so. They were all, in the beginning, very serious about going back to their countries. In the end, only one went back, one of them is half in the US and half in the country where she came from. It was really interesting to watch as I'm an immigrant myself, and it definitely resonated with me. The next day, I had a young man coming to fix my Wi-Fi from Haiti, who moved to this country to escape a very bad situation in Haiti. He is now in school and during the day makes money fixing people's TVs, Wi-Fi, and whatever you have. We got to talk a bit, even though he never, ever wants to go back to Haiti because it's so bad there, he still feels tugged between the two countries, the cultures. He misses certain things, family there, and I have been through similar things. I moved here because I had a husband who wanted to live in the US. I wasn't all that excited about it, but I thought for a couple of years, it will be fun to have that experience. We never went back, and now we divorced, I have two sons who live here, and they have children, my grandchildren. So, my family is now here, and yet there are days that I still feel, after all these years, like an outsider, trying to assimilate, trying to look at things in what I think is the American way, the two-party political system, that kind of thing. Some food that I absolutely can't stand. Now and then, I cook some food that I ate when I was young and growing up in Europe, to resolve with that homesickness, things that you tried to resolve. So, I don't think it ever goes away. I just wonder how many people in the United States, it seems it's such a mixing of different people, different countries, all the people that are now trying to come to the United States and live here and work here. And all these people have this homesickness, this feeling tucked and pulled between two countries. It's different when you live in a country where you've grown up and everyone is from the same country, and generations have lived in the same country. So maybe that sort of resonated with me. It made me think about living in another country and adjusting. I thought for these students, when they felt sad, and I could very well understand it. That's the end of my story.

Well, let's continue about a sudden shift from late summer to fall that always catches me by surprise. We had some very nice warm days last week, and all of a sudden, boom, it's dark, it's rainy, the temperature is down. It really feels like fall. And none of the other seasons have this sudden change that really affects you. There's always a fall, always sort of affects me. I get melancholy, I get sad. The summer is over. We're looking at the long winter coming up, I just don't know why, yet our seasons don't do that. The end of winter into spring, it's not that sudden, it's a slow process. Sometimes the winter goes on and on into March and April, and the same from the spring into the summer. There is not this quick change, but September, when the fall date starts, there is a very sudden switch to fall-like weather, and it just tells you it's over. Put away those T-shirts and all that and get the sweaters out, so that it always makes me a bit sad. So I'm not sure I'll get over it, but I will adjust. But things about fall and winter and all that because of the seasons, I'm not all that different. You may not have it. So maybe I should move to a warmer climate or something, although I do like the seasons and I'm sure I will be enjoying the changing leaves in a couple of weeks and all that. I'm sure we will get some more warmer sunny days again, but these last couple of days, it really got me, and I have to get over it.

K. It's not a very interesting story today, but I have an issue with procrastination. When there are things that are just boring, unpleasant, things I just don't like to do, I tend to find a zillion things to do around the house or elsewhere. I'm outside the house and avoid doing what I really need to do. At times, it really bothers me. I need to have a call with my lawyer, nothing serious, that's a lot of paperwork to be filled out and all that. I just don't like these kinds of things. So guess what? I plan to call the lawyer today. What did I do? Instead, I cleaned out two closets, did some cleanup in the kitchen, did some shopping that I really didn't need to do, and on and on. When it's 5:00, I have not called the lawyer, so here we are. I wish I could do something about it. I'm sure I can, but it's a tendency I've been struggling with for many years, I must say. So I don't know what else I can add to it, but even though I was so busy today doing all these things, at the end of the day, I did not call the lawyer. I didn't feel good about that, I felt frustrated that again I let it slip. I'm frustrated. So I need to work on that, and that's sort of my story for today. Not very interesting, I know. I really know what I need to do as well, but I have the tendency, and I've had it for a long time. But that's it for today.

I'm going to talk about history and perceptions of people throughout history, just something I thought about today. I think it's very interesting how historical figures get surrounded by stories which might or might not be true, but still somehow seem to bring out their character and convey the traits they have. For example, Alexander the Great has many stories about him doing various things, many of them are probably not true and just apocrypha made up by people later, but they all serve to demonstrate what kind of a person Alexander was. I think that kind of story or those kind of stories help dictate how a person is remembered through history. In 100 years from now, there are probably stories about people who change the world today, many of them are probably not true, but that doesn't really matter because it's these stories that tell the future what these people were like and it's these stories that will inspire people in the future. I think that's quite interesting. Alexander is not the only example. First, I think one of the most famous examples is probably Jesus, but it's also true of many mathematicians. I connect to those stories because I want to become a mathematician too, and mathematicians love constructing apocrypha of famous mathematicians, especially Gauss, Galois, and people like that. If you look into history, the lives of these people are genuinely interesting, although they tend to get imbalanced over time. I don't think this is necessarily negative, even though it's not historically accurate. This ties into some broader thoughts I have about mythology and how much you can learn about our culture, our time, through their mythology, because mythology is always evolving, but the way it evolves reflects the society it's evolving in. Sometimes I wonder if myths are being changed even today and I wonder what the future will infer about us that even we don't know right now. Personally, it means that anything you do that will be remembered is going to be exaggerated and will interest people, especially if it's worth remembering. If you persevere through difficult times to achieve something great, people will exaggerate the trouble you went through, but that also means you'll be remembered for going through so many struggles. I just think it's very interesting how stories and history interact and how culture influences the stories being told at the time and how the future can look back through these stories to understand the past. And I wonder where I'll be in it someday, if anyone even remembers.

Cool, right? So, like I just said, a bunch of near things happened to me today. It's quite a weird day, so I'm just going to tell you about it. The first thing that happened to me today was, yes, I attended this literature class on J.R. Tolkien, and I've never really attended anything quite like it. And it was quite fun, talking about Tolkien and his wife and his work. Then later in the day, I went sailing for the first time. We learned how to rig, bolt, tie some knots, and things like that, so that was quite interesting. I do have to take a test before I can sail, though. Hopefully, that will go well. We'll see. So, that's another new thing. Finally, I had to deliver a lecture instead of a professor who felt sick today. I had to teach only 20 students about living rooms. Very scary, but it was also very rewarding at the same time. I'm glad I did it. Once the lecture went on, the students got more and more engaged in the material. It seemed like almost everyone was paying attention and many of them were actually actively participating, which is great. I can't really ask for much more. I think, especially in a math class, it's been an encouraging day.

Yeah, I've come to realize that many things I do are motivated by the fear of failure, which is a weird thing, or at least one of the most effective motivators for me, I think. The fear of failure is stronger than the draw of success and sometimes I can work insane amounts that I felt really impossible, are insanely effective, and surprised myself just because I wanted to avoid failing. And even conversely, sometimes I'm okay with not achieving the best I can, as long as I can avoid failure. Not sure if that's a good thing. I think it feels not correct because I think motivating myself to do something because I want to do it is probably better than only motivating myself to do something because if I don't, then I will fail in some sense. I think it's made worse by the fact that I tend to block out failures from my mind and yeah, not sure. I find it hard to recall experiences where I felt if I try hard, if I can, I definitely can't think of many, many instances where I failed. But they're always pushed to some back corner of my mind, and they rarely resurface, which again might not be a good thing because it can make me repeat mistakes. Yeah, so motivation is a weird thing. There are some things which I am doing purely intrinsically, not because of the fear of failure, and that's good. But those are also harder to keep up than things for which there's a possibility of failing and that sort of forces me to keep up. Sometimes I push my limits and makes me do things that I didn't realize I could, which is an interesting thing and maybe good in some ways, but otherwise always being pushed from behind by that certain negative forces probably not good. I'm not really sure what to do about it.

A few months ago, I experienced what I know as the most fearful experience of my life. It was late in the evening and my body began to shake. Cold chills ran throughout my body and I lost control of my ability to breathe. My chest began pounding and I gasped for air. 

I called out to my partner, and suddenly he was there in front of me. I could not see him though, because my sight had been taken from me and my head began sweating. My partner grabbed me by the shoulders and began shaking me, and when that didn't work he lightly slapped my face. 

The chills made a change to heat and I broke out in a heated sweat. This was my first panic attack. It lasted no more than 15 minutes, but it felt like hours. My body was so weak after the fact and I could have sworn in that moment that I was going to die. 

My life seemed to flash before my eyes and all I could see was him. My partner, the love of my life, having to live a life without me in it. That is the day I realized that I had to go to therapy again. I made an appointment the very next day to seek help.

No, yeah. I think one story I have is just... I was thinking what to talk about, but the only thing which I haven't yet, I think, talked about is like with one of my friends from childhood. We've had, like a sort of, like a slow fall off where, I don't know, she expects me to do certain things or expects me to be in touch with her as much as she would like. But then, sometimes I'm not able to. I just need my own space in life, so that's always tricky. I feel like I don't really mind staying in touch with friends, but sometimes when someone expects you to, it just gets even more difficult. And it's not even like I don't want to stay in touch, it's just like sometimes I feel like her life is very complex. Most of the time, it just feels like a lot of emotional work. I don't know what to say to her, what to not say. Sometimes I think she thinks deeply and that makes me feel like I don't think deeply. It might also be just that, where I feel like whatever I'm doing is inadequate. Or sometimes she points things out, not things out which are not politically correct, but it seems which puts me off. Sometimes it makes me feel uncomfortable, I think. Just good, like I learn through that, but then I don't know, it just doesn't make me feel comfortable. So, I've just been trying to see how to maintain that friendship, and also, we have known each other for such a long time. So, I do want to stay friends, but I think we'll have to just reinvent our friendship.

A couple months ago my younger brother got married. I traveled back to my home town of St. Louis, Missouri for the event. I took my girlfriend along with me. It was her first trip to my home town ever. The trip started out great, we picked up our rental car and went to grab a pizza. 

The following day was my brother's wedding ceremony. We thought it had all been planned out thoroughly, but it turns out that nobody had checked the weather report. The day of the wedding came, it started out sunny, a hot day in late July. Clear blue skies and not a cloud to be seen. We were all so optimistic about the big day. The ceremony was scheduled for 6 PM at sunset, so it would start to cool down and allow for some reprieve from the heat of the day. In theory, that was a great idea. 

However, when my girlfriend and I pulled out of the driveway we noticed something new that we hadn't seen yet on the trip. Storm clouds moving in fast, and lots of them. Dark gray giants rose onto the horizon at a frightening pace. Lightning was visible in the distance as we began our drive to the wedding venue. We hoped and prayed that the storm would blow the other way, and that the outdoor wedding venue would be spared from this particular storm. Would we be able to get away with having the ceremony in decent weather? 

It became a race with time. As we drove to the wedding ceremony, it felt as though the clouds were following us and growing larger. As we arrived, I greeted my brother in the parking lot and asked if he thought it would rain. He said maybe, it depends how fast we can get this done. Everyone was present except for the minister, one of the few people who was completely essential to the process. 

As the minister arrived, it finally began to rain. It was raining on my brother's wedding day, I couldn't believe it, but luckily the ceremony was completed and we had a wonderful sunny reception the next day.

A memorable event that occurred in the past 3 months was preparing my eldest child for kindergarten. I worked really hard over the summer helping her set a schedule and routine that would be similar to her school day. She worked on many activities in order to memorize her contact information, writing, reading, and being able to handle her emotional well-being. 

As summer began to end, she seemed a little nervous to leave me and her little sister. I realized that there was no way to remove that feeling from her. Instead, I made plans for us to do activities when she finishes her school day. Planning ahead allows for her to feel like her school day really isn't too long. 

When school first began, she was very tired from the long day. I didn't realize how much her schedule had affected her, so I introduced "cuddle time", which is pretty fun for her. 

The most important aspects of my child starting school have been numerous. I learned how important my role as mom is for my kids. I am their literal compass, and that responsibility goes beyond just sending them off to school. I try to understand how her day is going, and what obstacles she faces each day. I meditate on how I can be influential in her education when she gets home from school. 

I love this new journey that we are on, and am actively preparing myself for the next several years of her school career.

Last weekend my husband and I came back from a trip together to Walt Disney World. We went without the kids and it was just the two of us. I was really excited because I love Disney and have a great time whenever I go there. 

The first day, we landed and went straight to a park. We went to Animal Kingdom and spend the entire day there. It was really hot, but I didn't care. We went on all the rides and had all the good snacks they had available in the park. 

The next day we went park hopping. We went to Epcot and the Magic Kingdom. 

The last day we went to Hollywood studios, which is my favorite of all the parks. I didn't want to leave. I feel like there is something magical about Disney and it makes me feel like a kid whenever I am there. 

I especially loved that it was just my husband and I there together. It was a lot more relaxed than when we take the kids along. We got to take our time and really enjoy everything. It was also nice spending time together, just him and I. We got to get away from everyday life and stress and reconnect. 

We shared romantic dinners and just enjoyed each others company away from it all. It was a memorable trip and I will never forget it.

For 7 months we'd been saving for a family vacation. The first family vacation we'd taken as a family of four (plus the in-laws). We'd invited my in-laws to join us an extra set of eyes to help keep an eye on the girls while we went to the beach (you never know when one of them is going to want to run off and we didn't want anyone alone in or near the water). 

Not only was this our first family vacation as a family of four, but it was to the beach. The girls had never been to the beach before. We went to The Outer Banks, or OBX as the locals and annual visitors call it. We were so excited to see the expression on our 1 yr old and 2 yr old faces; would it be joy or even possibly fear that they'd express. 

Shockingly the girls aren't as much of a fan of the beach as their mother is. The response of our 2 yr old as she first stepped into the sand " ew, yuck so dirty!" was a laugh for all of us but it should have also been a sign as to how they would like or dislike the beach. What kid doesn't enjoy getting a little dirty or at least one would normally think. But not our girls. 

We didn't last more than 30 minutes building sand castles and standing on the sand as the waves washed over our feet. They'd talk about going to the beach but as soon as we'd get there, they'd be bored or tired of walking on the sand. 

Although the beach itself didn't go over as well as we'd anticipated, at least the girls enjoyed getting away and "seeing" the beach from a distance. And at least we got pictures we can look back at...however short the time was. And the memories....oh the memories we created were priceless. 

Our first family vacation may not have gone over as well as we anticipated, but we all had a great time relaxing and enjoying time together. That's what matters anyway.

I work at a doctor's office and know all of the patients. I work with a lot of elderly people and I remember their names, their family, and things like that. One of my patients, whom I love dearly, has been getting sicker and sicker. She has been diagnosed with cancer and has not been responding to treatment well. Recently she has decided to stop with chemo and radiation because she doesn't want to spend the last few weeks of her life sick. It was a very hard decision for her to make, and for her family to accept. 

After she decided this, she came into the office and we talked about what we could do for her. When she was in she handed me a card and a small porcelain angel. She held my hand and told me she thought I was angel sent from heaven to help her during such an awful time. She said I gave her so much kindness and love, and that I felt more like family to her than a nurse. 

I felt my heart break into pieces, but also I felt so loved and appreciated. This woman was going through such a terrible time, and she wanted to comfort me. I hugged her and told her she was my family too, and that I love her very much. We held hands during her appointment, and I didn't want to let her go. 

Now I go see her on my days off and always bring flowers and some sweet tea. It's her favorite.

This whole thing was special to me and something that had an impact because some of the people that came into town hadn't seen me since I was a kid. One person in particular was someone who really loved to play jokes on people and tease them. I have so many memories of them in particular picking on me. I really resented it as a child because it was always in the presence of teachers and instead of doing anything about it, they laughed at him. It was some really early memories that I have of not feeling protected. 

As an adult, I know now that he was just a jokester and someone who loved pranks and joking around but as a kid, I saw it as torment and a bully. Nothing he did was even all that bad, just hiding and jump scaring everyone mostly. 

As an adult, it was the first time I had seen him in a long time and to be face to face with someone that I considered a bully growing up was so odd. Turns out, he was still joking around and kidding and being the same as I remembered him, but without the childlike thoughts of malice that I used to have. 

It really made an impact on me seeing him now with eyes that have grown and understood. I mentally forgave him for the pain he put me through as a kid. Some things latch on to you no matter what and being "picked on" for me was one of them. 

As an adult, I better understood things and seeing him do the same things he did to me (jump scaring, saying he was eating a cat when it was a regular burger, etc) seeing him do that to other kids, I see how it's harmless. 

It was a good case of when you are a kid, you can't understand anything. I felt a whole lot better after the situation. We ended up having a great talk about everything and I forgave him.

In the beginning of June this year i found out that i was pregnant with my second baby,. My husband i have been trying to conceive for about a year and we finally did it. We were very excited! We had our first ultrasound when i was about 6 weeks pregnant, we saw our little bean and saw a heartbeat which is always such a relieve. 

For some reason i was very scared about miscarriage even though i've never had one, i'm still young and pretty healthy. But for some reason i kept googling the chances of miscarriage. 

A week later i had another ultrasound to measure baby on good equipment and there wasn't a heartbeat anymore. My little baby passed away... I was in denial. I thought it was a mistake, i couldn't process it. I had 2 more ultrasounds in 2 different clinics to confirm this horrible diagnose. My baby's heart stopped beating a couple of days after we saw a heartbeat. It was so heartbreaking. One of the worst experiences in my life. 

I miscarried 3 weeks later in the ER. I had a horrible postpartum depression and had suicidal thoughts. I was in a very dark place but God surrounded me with so much love. I feel much better now.

I had been feeling pretty depressed lately, because I had been over-working myself. There wasn't much time in the day that I was taking to relax or reflect, and it was really starting to wear on me. I had just piled on more and more deadlines at work, thinking that I could do it all, but I was wrong. I was starting to get fatigued, and my work was suffering because of it. 

I was having an especially bad night, and I wanted to just give up, but I had a friend over who wouldn't let me. She told me that I needed to keep going, and basically that she believed in me, and in my ability to finish what I started. She told me that I was the hardest worker she knew, and that I was inspiring to her. She said that if I gave up, it would let her down, and that she knew I wouldn't let her down. 

That really helped, and it really touched me that she felt that way about me. It wasn't quite enough, though, as I was still very burned out. She told me to take the night off, and while I was relaxing, she went out and bought some things. She bought us some good food for dinner, as well as some nice wine to enjoy after. Then, she cooked me dinner, which was really good. 

After that, we just relaxed, listening to music and drinking wine, not having any care about work or deadlines. It was only one night, and it didn't solve the issue of being burned out, but it did give me some more fuel to keep on going and finish my projects. 

I am really thankful that she did that for me, and I am lucky to have her as a friend.

I recently moved back to a big city to look for a job after a few years. After graduating grad school in this particular city I had moved upstate. However last month I packed my suitcase and came back to the same city to look for a job. I came back for a few reasons, one being better career opportunities but also to connect with my friends. 

I stayed over at a friend's apartment for a few weeks while trying to land job interviews. There I rediscovered our friendship from years ago. We both went to college together and it was heart warming that despite years of not really communicating other than facebook messaging we got a long pretty well. It was almost a comforting sign. It was like the universe showing me positive signs that I might be on the right path. 

For a few years I was unsure of where I should be. However coming back to the city and meeting with old friends showed me how much I felt at home here. Right now I am working a temporary job to hold me over. However I really pray that I will find something stable here and am able to live and work here again. 

Although the city has changed I still love it. Finally I realized this is where I want to be.

Three months ago, my life completely changed for the better. I never thought the day would come where I would become a mother. At the age of thirty five and after years of trying to get pregnant and having two miscarriages, I had given up on having a child. My husband and I were looking into adopting but the process seemed pretty hard and there were no guarantees. 

In the end, I got pregnant out of no where and I was shocked to my core when I found out that I was pregnant and I was two months along. The fetus appeared healthy and I was on my way of becoming a mother. Three months ago, my daughter was born; a healthy 7 pound 3 oz. No one or nothing could have prepared me for the profound love I have for my daughter and I feel so lucky to have the opportunity to be a mother to my sweet girl. I love her so much and my husband and I are so very happy. We can't wait to see what the future holds and we are secretly hoping to be blessed with another child. 

The changes in our lives have been mostly positive and some negatives. The positives are having our child and being able to make life long memories with her. Our families have been great through out my pregnancy and they have been so helpful in the last couple of months. 

On the other hand, the negatives are not getting enough sleep. I feel tired and excited most of the time, and there are times when I doze off every chance I get. The worry for our child is horrible at times and its a major drawback for us because in the back of our mind we feel like this beautiful experience might not last and can be easily taken away from us.

Two months ago I married the love of my life. It is by far the most memorable day of my life. We met in high school, became teen parents, and had been dating for a little over 14 years. We had a long 5 year engagement, just to ensure that our wedding day was perfect. We paid for everything and planned everything on our own, which I think adds to the memory of our special day. We both had input and we tailored our decisions to stay true to our love story, as well as highlighting our very different personalities. 

It was a great day and when we read our vows, people cried. We had a very intimate setting, very close friends and family only, and I think it made it that much more special. We really just focused on ourselves and each other, something a lot of couples forget to do. 

I've heard so many times, from friends and family, that they wish they could go back and do it all over again. I've heard a lot of stories about how the day flew by and that they never took the time to actually enjoy it. A lot of people regret the decisions they make when it comes to their wedding day. They wish they would have had a smaller or a less expensive wedding. A lot of my friends and family believe they wasted a large sum of money on one single day and ended up being in debt afterwards. 

We took all of those stories and we decided to not let that be our story. We bought everything with cash, nothing as a loan or on credit. We made our own smorgasbord of food and desserts. We treated it like Thanksgiving. It was awesome and delicious. We worried less about being flashy and classy and more about being comfortable and memorable. We wore what we wanted and didn't have a dress code for our guests. There was no rehearsal dinner, no huge reception. We told people to come as you are and bring their own drinks. 

Everyone really enjoyed just relaxing, eating good food, and letting loose. It was beautiful, laid back and there's nothing I would change about our special day.

I ventured into work like any other day. I was tired and fed up with the conditions of my work environment and pay on top of that. On this day, I planned on spending my entire evening looking for another job. 

Around lunch time I was called in for a random meeting. I figured I was somehow in trouble for something. Turns out, it was completely opposite of what I had expected. My superior sat me down and he had a stack of papers in his hand. It was a contract stating my terms of employment would be changing if I agreed. My title was being changed along with my pay rate. I was just stunned, because I felt like my hard work was often dismissed and not even recognized. 

After going through this contract, I signed my name, thanked my superior, and nearly skipped out of this conference room. My new pay rate would take effect in my next pay check. It was a fairly significant increase, so I was excited to see what kind of checks I would be making now. 

With my promotion, came a new office as well. Overall it was a good day. Very unexpected, but in the end I was appreciative my hard work had finally been recognized.

Today was one of the saddest days of my life. It started early in the day, and my parents came by and picked me up at my house. Everyone was in a very somber mood, but it was sunny and quite warm. We drove out to a church about thirty minutes away near where my mom grew up, and while driving I couldn't help but think back to all the good memories I had with my cousin. She was always so happy and nice and just fun to be around. But now, that was all gone, and all I had were the memories that were going over in my mind. 

Arriving at the church and seeing all of my family, it was hard. It was just so sad, all of it. Seeing my aunt was the hardest part I think, but I knew then that she was strong and was going to be able to get past this. My uncle is an ordained pastor, so he was able to help with the service and I think that helped ease some of the pain. 

After the service we all went to the cemetery and gathered up on the hill in the shade. Seeing the final resting place really hit me hard, I started to cry much harder than I had been all day at that point. All of the memories and the final shock to my brain that she was never coming back, made me very sad, and made me miss her dearly. 

We then all met at a local place where they served a late lunch and we had some drinks. It was good to see so many of my family, but at the same time, so sad, because I thought that we shouldn't be seeing each other, at least not for this reason. 

I didn't really know how to feel when we left and I made it back home. I was deeply saddened, and just thought of how my aunt, uncle, and cousins felt. I know that life had changed for them forever, and now life was starting again without their dear one, and that hurt me again. But my family is strong, and stronger together, and I know we will get through this like we will any other tragedy that comes our way.

I was in a 5 year relationship with a woman who lived in another country. When we decided to be together, I remember like it was yesterday. Getting my passport, and buying the plane ticket seemed small in the entire thing. What was really the big deal was getting on an airplane for the very first time. Being afraid of flying made this hard enough, but the excitement of going to another country on the other side of the world to meet the woman I loved overcame all of it. 

She and I made plans to meet up at the airport when I arrived, and what we where going to do. When I got there, departed the plane, went through immigration, and got my belongings she was no where to be seen. I waited for several hours outside the airport, trying to call her phone. When she finally answered, she told me she could not come to the airport. She asked me to just get a hotel and she would see me the next day. 

I was left in a foreign country alone I had no idea about, holding flowers and chocolates I brought for her. Looking foolish, I then decided to just get a taxi to a nice hotel for the night to relax from the jet lag, and decide what to do from there. 

The next morning, she called me. She said she could not meet me that day either, maybe the next day she could. Her family called me, randomly, and said out of respect for me going all the way there they felt it was the right thing to do to tell me my girlfriend of 5 years had another boyfriend, and was pregnant. That she had been scamming me the entire time.

My wife and I had been teaching my son how to ride his bike for quite a while. He was having trouble learning. We started out with the traditional style of the parent holding the seat and the handlebars while the child pedals. We ran several days of trials this way. It was hard for my son to realize the mechanics. 

I would hold the seat and he would begin to lean into me. He wouldn't try to adjust himself, but would rely on me to keep him upright. It wasn't working. 

I looked online for some suggestions. This was a first for both my wife and I. I found one post advising to have the child sit on the seat and walk the bike themselves, then when they have enough momentum, start pedaling. 

This method made total sense to me. It seemed to teach them the natural motions while still being safe. My son tried this method a few times. He was starting to get the balance down that he needed. 

He finally walked it out and began to pedal. He went the length of the driveway and now he is a full-fledged bike rider. It was one of the proudest moments of my life.

The most recent memorable event was learning that my mom has a personality disorder call Narcissist Personality Disorder. It explained so much of my youth and adult life living with her and interacting with her. 

 

My siblings and I were never encouraged to be together, to congratulate each other, to help each other by her. We were only told of the negative things that each one had supposedly done and that we all had some type of grudge against each other. Therefore we all grew apart and did not trust each other. We were not a close family or even a fake family. We all basically just knew of each other. 

 

Learning that she has the disorder put a lot into perspective but does not allow for resolution or closure with her. Even with her diagnosis she does not admit anything. She still wants to be the "pit stop" among the children. 

 

Unfortunately, I see the same pattern in my siblings and myself. At this point I cannot communicate with her. She has a great burden about me from my childhood that she has not yet acknowledged. So I am always in her mind trying to retaliate. She tells this to the family and they do not know which is truth and have chosen to believe her. 

 

I am leaving them and her alone as it will do no good until someone else is on the receiving end of the vitriol.

I went to a nearby city to meet up with family members for a very memorable family reunion. There were about 12 of us in all. We went out to dinner at a very nice Chinese restaurant. 

My brother, who is a math professor, is very precise in his language. He requires precision from everyone around him. He started asking a lot of questions about the food options. 

The waiter became offended, even though there was nothing offensive about the questions. But the waiter didn't like my brother's tone of voice. At one point he stepped back and said "I don't need to be talked to like that." 

It was kind of sad. I realized that my brother has no idea how he comes off when he's in professorial mode. My brother ended up getting something he didn't really love, because he felt bad about what happened, and had decided to stop asking questions. 

In the end, the food was good, the company was good, the moment was forgotten, and the waiter got a pretty nice tip. And it was good to see my brother. We had an excellent rest of the reunion. I'm probably the only one who still recalls the moment.

In July I went to rehab. My husband and I had been fighting about finances a lot and my absences from work. For years I had been telling myself that I would quit drinking and quit smoking cannabis, but every day I would tell myself I would start tomorrow. I realized I couldn't do it on my own so I made the call, was accepted into a program to start the next day, and after a restless night I set off to rehab. I bought a pack of cigarettes on the way there, my first in nearly three years. 

I was so nervous as I sat in the lobby waiting to be called. What would the days look like? Would I be taken seriously since my addiction was to a substance everyone says you can't get addicted to? What would the others be like? Would I be the youngest or the oldest? Finally my name was called and I spent the next few hours signing paperwork, paying for treatment up front, and meeting with a medical professional. 

I was told to strip and put on scrubs, though the pair of pants they tried to give me were much too small, and I laughed for the first time that day when they hardly slid over my knees. I was able to keep my own sweatpants, but the horrid green scrub shirt made me feel like the inmates I've seen on tv. 

Eventually they dropped me off down in the kitchen where a group of people were playing Cards Against Humanity. I didn't know what the plan was for the rest of the evening but that half hour spent watching these people laugh gave me some time to get my bearings. I heard names and tried to match them with faces. I saw two others in scrubs and realized it was their first day too. Some faces were happy; others looks tired, worn down, half asleep. 

Dinner was challenging because I don't eat animal products and usually had the assistance of marijuana to quell the nausea. The nurse offered me Ativan but I refused; I asked her for some when I threw up some sad lettuce and yellow rice a few minutes later. 

During one of the cigarette breaks I familiarized myself with the others there and was convinced to sign up for a yoga class. The class was relaxing, but I cried the whole time. I was so scared, for myself, for my husband, for the future. 

When it was all said and done I went into my room, lay down on the small twin mattress with the plastic cover, and cried myself to sleep.

I know it may sound silly but it was quite emotional to finish what I now consider to be my favorite book. It is difficult to even come up with a single favorite book but I did in this case. I liked it so much , maybe because at 59, I am aging and related well to the characters. I am also a Texan. 

Lonesome Dove is about two aging ex-Texas Rangers that feel the need to have one last great adventure. This last adventure takes the form of a cattle drive from south Texas north to Montana (if memory serves me well). There are many other characters involved with different backgrounds that could very well have books of their own. The adventures abound and there really isn't a dull moment in the entire book. 

Larry McMurtry excels at character development to the point that I felt as though I knew them. He also excels at plots and sub-plots that are very compelling. While it isn't "War and Peace" long, it is a rather long book but I wished it was longer when I finished it. 

I was very sad when I finished reading Lonesome Dove. It was like losing a playmate, maybe even a friend. I wondered what I was going to do for reading next. I ended up researching similar books written by Larry McMurtry. I did find other similar books that were written about the western United State at around the same time period but it just didn't match the colorful characters in Lonesome Dove. 

Maybe it was because I was born in the panhandle of Texas, my dad was a real cowboy and I could relate better to many of the things mentioned in the book. As such the others paled in comparison.

About two months ago, my family and I went to the beach in California. There was a beach volleyball tournament that we wanted to see. We got up early in the day and were already at the beach around 10 am. We swam, sunbathed, and hung out while we waited for the tournament to start. The weather was perfect and it felt great that my family was together for the whole day. I got to catch up with my siblings since I had not seen them in a while. 

Then, the tournament started and we nervously and anxiously watched and cheered on our favorite team. The team ended up winning and we were so excited. Around 8pm we started packing up and walking home. 

When we got home, we realized we all got very badly sunburned. I guess in the excitement of it all, we forgot to reapply sunscreen throughout the day. We immediately went to the drugstore to get some aloe vera and pain killers. My brothers filled up the bathtub with a bunch of ice and soaked in it. We all got sunburned in the past, but never this badly. 

It was interesting to see how much we all helped each other. My brothers were wetting towels for everyone, and mom was making sure we were staying hydrated. I was in charge of the aloe and my dad was entertaining us to distract us. 

We had plans to go to dinner that night, we even made reservations. We all wanted to go so we started getting ready, but even the clothes were painful on our skin. Since we would all probably be cranky, we decided it is best to just cancel dinner and stay in. 

That day was so memorable to me because it started out as the best day I had in a long time, but then it ended with my whole family in excruciating pain. Despite everything this day brought us all together as a family and I am so happy it did.

I can remember and think a lot about a trip I took with my husband to the Bahamas! It was a wonderful and relaxing trip for both of us. We flew to Miami and then a short flight to the Bahamas. We took a taxi to the huge hotel we were staying at. On the way, I could see a lighthouse and clear blue water. We both felt so good to be there. The weather was perfect with a warm breeze and full sun! 

After getting our room near the pool and beach area, we went straight away and got lunch and walked around the area. It had many restaurants, gambling areas, pools, beaches, water sports, shopping, exercise rooms, massage rooms and dinner entertainment! Everyday we had things to do and see. 

There were many memorable things I did there, like going down a huge slide with my husband behind me at once. Getting my hair braided on the white sand with two lovely ladies with a drink in my hand having interesting conversation. It was fun to pick out beads for my hair. 

I think one of the most memorable was when my husband took me to the Columbia Emerald store and helped me pick out a ring I like for a memory of the trip. It is a beautiful emerald ring in gold with an oval shaped emerald in the middle and smaller ones on both sides. Everyday I wear the ring and its makes me so happy to remember all the fun times we had there. 

Needless to say we want to go back. Its a great place to visit and relax. Spending time with the one you love is the best!

This story is about my family's recent vacation to Myrtle Beach, and the subsequent heart attack my wife's father suffered while there. We had planned a week long vacation to the beach, travelling from Ohio in order to spend time with my family, including my parents and brother, and my wife's parents, and our 2 children. 

After having fun for 4 days, my father in law awoke Thursday morning complaining of some pain in his jaw and heartburn. My father in law and his wife felt that they should conservatively go to the hospital to get checked out. Unfortunately, a blood test returned with slightly elevated enzyme numbers, meaning some minor heart damage may have occurred. No problem, we thought, just a few more tests and a ruined day of vacation. 

Well, after heart catheter, the really bad news came in. My father in law would need quadruple bypass surgery immediately. They scheduled him for surgery Monday morning, and he would have to stay in Myrtle Beach for another few weeks after the surgery until he was allowed to fly home. 

What I will remember the most is visiting my father in law on Friday morning at the hospital and letting him visit with his grandchildren. He was so stone faced and obviously scared and in mental anguish. I gave him a hug goodbye, since I had to drive my kids home on Saturday, and he was in tears. It was very painful to witness that. 

Fortunately, my wife was going to stay with her mom and dad for a few more days to get through the surgery and help any way she could. In excellent news, my father in law had a perfect surgery and is now recovering and getting stronger every day. 

The whole sequence of events is a good reminder to take life one day at a time, and appreciate all that we are given. Hopefully we have many more years of his presence to make many more memories.

It was the day that I met my husband. He came into my life and affected me in so many ways and for which I really do not have words to describe. Yet, I will try my best to portray how his coming into my life completely changed me and gave me a whole new world to look at. 

One of the things that I noticed immediately when I met my husband was how safe and secure he made me feel. I remember meeting him that very first day and realizing how good I felt just being with him. It was as if a burden had been lifted from my shoulders. I suddenly felt free and relaxed, as if I had to worry about nothing in life ever again. 

He would be very supportive of my ideas and my decisions and would encourage me to go ahead and do what I wanted the most. He provided me with the background support that I had always needed to further my plans but had felt so insecure before. He had a knack of making me laugh and feel good about myself and whatever was going on at that time. 

Aside from making me feel emotionally stable, safe, and secure, he also made me feel very secure financially. He made it look so easy, as if I would never have to worry about money ever again. He made me feel that I could trust him with no matter what. 

This is perhaps the reason that I married him in the first place, because of how he good he made me feel about myself: very safe, secure, and sound.

Sarah got the job in Amsterdam. She's really excited, and I'm happy for her, but I'm worried too. I know the doctors say her tumor is not aggressive, and that her situation is good, but it's still cancer. Amsterdam has excellent health care options, but her doctors here are very good and know her case. She says it's not a big deal and that she'll still be doing a lot of her tests when she flies back here, but still. 

The insurance situation is complicated, too. She says her company deals with this sort of thing all the time, and that they know what to do, but there's a difference between someone who's insurance is just in case and her situation. She can't afford any lapses or mistakes, and I'm not convinced everything will work out as smoothly as she thinks. 

Still, she's incredibly excited, and this does seem like a great opportunity for her. It's not my place to tell her what she can and can't do, so all I can do is be supportive and try to make sure she's doing everything she can to stay healthy. Not that she needs much help, she's been incredibly motivated not to let this thing stop her. That's probably part of why she's so all-in about this job. 

At least, for the first time in her life, she's moving and I don't have to help. Her company is taking care of everything, and except for one chair that I grudgingly agreed to store for her I don't have to lift a finger. She may or may not get the chair back. 

I hope I look back on this entry and see it as the start of good things and me being too protective. I'm still worried, though.

Last Friday night, one of our dogs attacked the other dog. We have two dogs. One is a hound mix around 60 pounds, Roxy. Our other dog is a terrier mix around 30 pounds, Sadie, and she has a seizure disorder. They both recently just turned three and have spent the majority of their lives together.
